While some of the weapons are rifles, ``This is really a handgun city and a handgun area,'' Pedersen said. ``We're finding more than half the guns picked up in crime now are semiautomatic handguns, and that appears to be growing, based on the last couple of years.'' In many cases, these are not the now-infamous Saturday Night Specials, cheap handguns bought on the spur of the moment. ``We find a lot of high-quality firearms, a direct result of the drug trade,'' Pedersen said. ``They can afford high quality, and they buy them.'' Some are the same weapons used by police forces around the country, 9mm semiautomatic handguns that cost $500 to $700 apiece, he said. At the same time, many of the guns are small and concealable .25-caliber semiautomatic pistols that cost about $200, he said. The NRA contends that Washington's murder rate _ the highest in the nation _ demonstrates that gun control doesn't work. Gun control laws vary widely in the major cities with some of the highest murder rates in 1988. The top 12 among the 35 U.S. cities with 400,000 or more people included four cities with no gun control measures, including Detroit, which has the second highest murder rate. Seven more of the 12 had relatively strong gun control laws, while one, Miami, had a three-day cooling off period for a gun purchase, but no background check on the buyer. At the same time, Honolulu, covered by a strong state gun control measure, showed the lowest murder rate among the 35 largest cities. Law enforcement officials and gun control advocates say there's more to the issue than whether an individual city has strong controls. They say Washington's location _ carved out of Maryland and Virginia with virtually no natural boundaries other than the easily crossed Potomac River _ makes its handgun ban virtually unenforceable. ``In Washington, you can drive across the river and purchase handguns,'' said Susan Whitmore of Handgun Control Inc. ``Until this last year, Virginia had one of the weakest gun laws in the country.'' New York City has the same problem, she said. ``More than 90 percent (of the guns used in New York crimes) come from other states with very weak laws,'' Whitmore said. ``That's why we believe we need a national law.'' A new law in Virginia that took effect Nov. 1, 1989, requires an immediate background check prior to the purchase of assault-style weapons and most handguns. A person wishing to buy a gun must complete an application and the gun dealer must call the Virginia State Police to get approval for the sale. As of Dec. 31, 1989, Virginia officials had approved 9,834 sales _ each of which could involve numerous guns _ and rejected 109 applications, said state police Lt. R. Lewis Vass, who runs the program. The program has produced an unexpected dividend: the capture of three fugitives, one from Florida and two from New Jersey. By state law, police have until the close of business the day after a gun-purchase application has been rejected to tell the gun dealer the rejection is confirmed or a search of records found the sale could be made. As a result, some people rejected initially have returned to gun stores the next day to get the final decision. In three cases, police were waiting when the fugitives returned, Vass said. Officials also are hoping prosecution of certain gun dealers will curb illicit sales. Donald P. Percival, a former U.S. Park Police officer who owned gun stores in Virginia, and James S. Chapman, a former D.C. police officer and retired Secret Service uniformed agent, were convicted in November of illegally selling semiautomatic handguns to an 18-year-old drug dealer who resold or traded the weapons for drugs in Washington. While Whitmore said she was encouraged by Virginia's new law, Pedersen said it's still too early to tell what impact it will have on gunfire in Washington, saying the problem occurs when legitimate purchasers in Virginia provide weapons to people who would be ineligible to purchase them legally. Gun control groups want national laws, but one law enforcement official says regional controls might be sufficient. ``If you were in a town that had mountains or deserts around it and people had to travel four hours and take two interstates to get to the area, I can see how you might control a problem like this,'' the officer said. But in Washington, ``It's like walking across the street to get a hamburger. We're one large urban area here. It's hard to keep guns out of D.C. when there are no natural borders.''

DOC.HEAD: Margaret Kelly, Mother of Princess Grace, Dies at 91
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf, `Mrs. Kelly, to CORRECT name of surviving daughter to Conlan sted Conland; SUBS last graf to add location of funeral.
DOC.TEXT: Margaret Kelly, mother of the late Princess Grace of Monaco and matriarch of the famed Kelly clan of Philadelphia, died at a convalescent home here. She was 91. Mrs. Kelly died at 8:45 a.m. Saturday of pneumonia, a spokesman for the Linwood Convalescent Center said. She had been a resident of the nursing home since 1982 and had suffered several strokes in recent years. A former beauty queen and magazine cover girl, she was known both for her own accomplishments and those of her husband and children, particularly her daughter, actress Grace Kelly, who later married Prince Ranier of Monaco. Princess Grace died of injuries suffered in an automobile accident in September 1982. Mrs. Kelly's husband, John B. Kelly Sr., was an Olympic rowing champion who parlayed his skills as a bricklayer into a construction empire. He died in 1960. Born on Dec. 13, 1898, the former Margaret Majer met her future husband at a Philadelphia swimming pool when she was just a teen-ager. They married in 1924. Earlier, in her early 20s, she appeared on the covers of several national and Philadelphia magazines. An accomplished swimmer and athlete, Mrs. Kelly was the first director of women's athletics at the University of Pennsylvania. Mrs. Kelly is survived by two daughters, Margaret R. Conlan of Philadelphia and Lizanne K. LeVine of Gladwyne, Pa.; 13 grandchildren; and 17 great-grandchildren. The couple's only son, John B. Kelly Jr., also rowed in the Olympics, was at one time president of the U.S. Olympic Committee and served on the Philadelphia City Council. He died in 1985. Funeral services were planned for Tuesday in Philadelphia.

DOC.HEAD: This Doghouse Has Tails Wagging
LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: In the heart of this fashionable Washington suburb, there's a yuppie dream house that's gone to the dogs. The luxurious amenities of the doghouse that Richard T. Ziegler built for Crissy, his white German shepherd, and J.R., his Doberman pinscher, would strain the hyperbolic lyricism of a real estate ad writer. Their doggie digs feature a redwood cathedral ceiling, Italian porcelain tile flooring, solid brass fixtures, a terra cotta chimney for the fake flagstone fireplace, cedar-shake roof and double-paned windows with space heater to keep it toasty warm on winter nights. Outside, there's a kidney-shaped pool surrounded by a patio deck and rock garden. And all for only $15,000 plus. Ziegler had the doghouse designed as a miniature, 8-foot version of the $3.5 million ``contemporary Victorian'' mansion that Ziegler built for himself on 25 acres of rolling woodland in the Virginia countryside west of Washington. He says he plans to build an equally lavish ``guest cottage'' below the doggie pool to house Crissy and J.R.'s overnight visitors. It's a doggone shame, but the two dogs hardly ever use their posh living quarters, except to flop down on the cool tile floor for relief on hot summer days, Ziegler says. Unlike the doghouse that Jim and Tammy Bakker built, this one isn't airconditioned. So far, Crissy and J.R. have only dipped their paws in the pool, Ziegler says, although they enjoy sprawling on the deck to spy on squirrels and other wildlife scampering in the woods. ``They spend most of the time in my house,'' he said. ``They sleep on their own bed right in the master bedroom. You don't tell a Doberman where he's going to sleep.'' Ziegler, 53, a developer whose companies have built two dozen shopping centers in metropolitan Washington, North Carolina and the San Francisco Bay area, isn't the sort of man who'd nail a few pieces of plywood together to make a doghouse, like most folks. Ziegler believes in going first class. His own backyard has a gigantic, heated swimming pool with three waterfalls gurgling past rock gardens and a bubbling whirlpool bath. The main house, with its vaulted ceilings and wide glass windows, is covered with 4{ miles of redwood siding and 320 tons of flagstone from the Blue Ridge mountains. His five-car garage is full. It's currently occupied by a white Lincoln stretch limo with telephones, bar, TV set and curving white leather sofa; a white Jaguar convertible; a couple of neo-classic Excalibur and Zimmer touring cars; and a four-wheel drive vehicle ``that belongs to my dogs.'' Ziegler also keeps a 53-foot Italian motor yacht berthed in Miami. Not bad for a bread truck driver's son from Suitland, Md., who couldn't afford to attend college, but took night classes, raised a family and worked 90-hour weeks for two decades to build a booming construction business. Does Ziegler have any qualms about spending more than $15,000 for a doghouse while homeless people are sleeping in the streets of Washington? ``Not at all,'' he says. ``That's why I worked all my life, so I could do things like that.''

DOC.HEAD: President in First 6 Months Acts Boldly, Though With Little Success
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: In the six months he has been president, Carlos Menem has boldly addressed Argentina's biggest problems, so far with little success. To overcome inflation and recession that forced his predecessor to leave office 22 weeks early, Menem put up for sale state companies his Peronist Party nationalized or created four decades ago. To reduce tensions in the armed forces, he called off the trials of officers accused of kidnapping, torture and murder during the 1976-83 dictatorship, pardoning several hundred soldiers along with a handful of one-time, left-wing terrorists. To restore ties with Great Britain severed during the 1982 Falkland Islands war, Menem set aside the thorny issue of sovereignty over the South Atlantic archipelago. Consulates reopened in Buenos Aires and London last month; full diplomatic relations are pending. ``He said nothing about any of this during his campaign, which focused on charisma and nationalism,'' historian Felix Luna said in an interview. ``The change has been night to day.'' Nevertheless, Menem's willingness to tackle head-on issues his predecessor, Raul Alfonsin, ignored or tried to finesse has not moved Argentina from the brink of hyperinflation, social unrest and military insurrection. The cost of living in December soared by at least 50 percent _ eight times the November rate. Inflation for 1989 topped 4,200 percent. Real wages have shrunk to about one-half the level of a year ago. Underemployment and unemployment total 16 percent. Teachers, police officers, bus drivers, unskilled laborers and many others earn about $100 a month, or less. All have held strikes since Menem took office. ``Wages are absolutely insufficient ... and if prices don't come down ... people aren't going to have enough even to buy food,'' said Cesar Jaroslavsky, leader of the opposition Radical Civic Union bloc in the House of Deputies. Noting that hundreds of border guards were deployed last month in Rosario, Argentina's second-biggest city and the site of food riots in May and June, Jaroslavsky added, ``I think social unrest is a real risk.'' The army remains bitterly divided between loyal officers and rebels who staged three insurrections against Alfonsin, president from December 1983 through last July. ``There is no possibility of a military coup,'' said Rosendo Fraga, executive director of the Union for the New Majority Studies Center. ``For that, you would need three things: at least some international support, at least some public support, and an efficient military leader. In Argentina, none of those three factors exists.'' Only Menem's harshest critics blame his policy ``errors'' for Argentina's continued economic and political morass. Others note ills run so deep that a major endeavor in one area fails to resolve it at one fell swoop, and provokes problems somewhere else. The government's confiscation of several billion dollars worth of certificates of deposit last week stabilized the austral and lowered interest rates from 600 percent a month. But it also dried up funds for investment and may worsen the existing recession. It also eroded public confidence in the government and the banking system. ``The government is disoriented and Menem doesn't know what to say,'' said Juan Sanabria, a dentist, as he waited in line outside a bank. ``Everytime he opens his mouth, he makes things worse.'' If Menem, a career politician who was jailed nearly five years during the last dictatorship, has ignored tradition and struck out in new directions, he also has shown himself to be unpredictable, volatile, and willful. If a plan fails or a minister lets him down, Menem changes to another. Three of the eight Cabinet ministers he appointed in July have been replaced. On Dec. 10, a new, official exchange rate was set. On Dec. 18, controls on foreign exchange were lifted. Menem allowed long-time aide Eduardo Curia to draft a plan to ``dollarize'' prices and wages in an effort to stabilize the austral. At the last minute, Menem changed his mind. Curia resigned from the Economy Ministry days later. ``Menem has correct intuitions, but he has demonstrated he has little liking for the routine of government,'' said Fraga of the center-right Studies Center. Among the sharpest criticism of Menem is that having pushed through legislation giving him authority to sell state companies and cut the budget, he has done neither. Also, some accuse him of spending too much time kissing snow queens at ski resorts, driving in car and boat rallies, playing soccer and tennis, and playing host to foreign dignitaries. Menem tells Argentines his government is on the right track and has accomplished more in six months than previous governments did in six years. As much as he has wavered in other areas, Menem stands firmly behind plans to sell the state airline, railroad and other public companies; to deregulate the oil and other state industries; to remove government controls of wages, prices, exchange and interest rates; and to cut state spending and encourage foreign investment. ``From my point of view, this is the last serious crisis,'' he said in an interview published last week by the news magazine Gente. ``The important thing (for me) is not to lose calm, to be a good pilot in a storm.''

DOC.HEAD: Rail Strike Reduces Service in Spain
DOC.TEXT: A strike by engineers of the national railway RENFE reduced service between major cities Sunday as Spaniards returned home after the Epiphany holiday, management and union officials said. The 24-hour strike, the third since Christmas, forced RENFE to cancel international service to all cities except Lisbon and Geneva. RENFE officials said 53 domestic intercity trains ran, far fewer than normal, while commuter train service was reduced by 30 percent. Management said about 15 percent of the engineers struck, but union representatives put the figure at 60 percent. Management and unions that represent the majority of RENFE's 50,000 employees oppose the strike because the engineers are seeking to negotiate a pay increase separate from the existing collective bargaining agreement.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Coalition Crumbling After Only Three Days
DOC.TEXT: A coalition created by six East German reform movements to challenge the Communists crumbled Sunday just three days after being formed, underscoring the difficulties pro-democracy forces face in May elections. While Communist Party leader Gregor Gysi kicked off his party's campaign in Potsdam, one of the pro-democracy groups announced it was leaving the coalition, and the largest group said it preferred to run candidates independently. The Communist Party has been stripped of its constitutional mandate to rule and has been tarnished by corruption scandals, but the lack of a credible alternative has left it in control of the government and better positioned for the election than the fractured opposition. Massive street demonstrations and the exodus of thousands forced the Communists to grant historic concessions last year, including the promise of free elections May 6. Dozens of citizens' groups pressing for social, political, environmental and economic reforms have sprung up since the Oct. 18 removal of Communist leader Erich Honecker and the nation's turn toward democracy. Social Democratic leader Steffen Reiche said Thursday his party had joined with New Forum, Democratic Awakening, Democracy Now, the Initiative for Peace and Human Rights, and the United Left to form Election Alliance 90. But the United Left announced Sunday it had withdrawn from the coalition, telling East Germany's official ADN news agency that the group had been ``misleadingly presented'' in the announcement Thursday. Bernd Gehrkes of United Left said his group was open to other alliances ``if suitable common policies can be worked out.'' New Forum, the largest of the pro-reform groups with more than 200,000 members throughout East Germany, held a strategy congress in Leipzig over the weekend and announced its union with the other groups was limited. The 150 New Forum delegates said the election of individual, independent candidates was preferable to voting for political parties or alliances, and that New Forum candidates would rather run alone. Regulations on campaigning and balloting are to be set out under a new election law, a draft of which is expected to be published before Parliament meets Thursday. Differences among opposition groups also have become apparent during the weekly negotiations among the various reform movements, the Communists and other political parties. The confrontation between the fractured opposition groups and the Communists could result in collapse of the talks and further destabilization of Premier Hans Modrow's transitional government. The talks began Dec. 7 to provide a forum for drafting reforms and airing the views of citizens' groups that have no representation in the government. Democratic Awakening has threatened to pull out of them Monday unless Modrow's government shows proof the former state security force has been disbanded. New Forum said it, too, would leave the talks if Parliament acts to form a secret police force before the elections. ADN reported in December that the government had abolished the once-feared secret police agency. But media reports have since contended some armed units continue to operate. Modrow said in an interview Sunday with Austrian television that a security force is needed to prevent the spread of right-wing extremism in East Germany. Communists have made the recent rise in neo-Nazi incidents a major theme of the election campaign and an argument against reunification with West Germany. A ``greater Germany'' would awaken concerns in the rest of Europe, Modrow told Austrian television. Opposition forces consider Modrow's Cabinet to have limited authority because it was chosen by a Communist-controlled Parliament that was not democratically elected. New Forum also insisted during the meeting in Leipzig that delegates should be assigned to government ministries and commissions to give the opposition a voice in national affairs prior to the elections.

DOC.HEAD: Would-Be Buyers of Video Recorders Lay 5-Day Siege to Russian Stores
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of people clamoring to buy imported VCRs surrounded stores in a Russian city for five days, and some even staged a hunger strike and protests demanding the chance to buy the precious goods, a newspaper said Sunday. It was the latest show of discontent among Soviets, who are deprived of many consumer goods. The newspaper Sovietskaya Rossiya described the incident in the Russian city of Yaroslavl as a ``video uprising.'' The disturbance began when word went out that imported VCR's for workers who had earned foreign currency had been delivered to a store in Yaroslavl, an industrial city about 125 miles northeast of Moscow. About 200 people immediately surrounded the store and sat through the night, demanding they be given the chance to buy the VCR's as well. Two other stores that also received shipments were similarly besieged, the newspaper said. At dawn of the fourth day, the angry residents launched a protest on the central town square. Eventually, city authorities persuaded the workers who were to receive the VCRs to share some of their spoils with the public, the newspaper said. But when the store at the center of the turmoil did not immediately begin selling some of its 158 VCRs to all customers the next day, a group of citizens declared a hunger strike. Finally, after five days of turmoil, a happy buyer walked out of the store with the first VCR, called the local TV station and declared: ``Victory! The Panasonic is in my hands!'' Sovietskaya Rossiya said this was the first time in Yaroslavl history that videocassette recorders were sold freely to the public. Traditionally, imported electronic goods have been quietly distributed only to the party and government elite or sold on the black market, where a VCR can cost as much as $6,400. These days, under the Kremlin's economic reforms, factories that earn foreign currency are generally allowed to decide for themselves how to spend it, and they frequently buy Western consumer goods for their workers. Residents of the central Russian city of Sverdlovsk took their frustration to the streets in similar unrest Dec. 29, when a crowd upset by the shortage of vodka gathered downtown and halted city transport. Communist Party officials soothed them and flooded the stores with vodka, and the crowd dispersed when people rushed off to buy their bottles, the newspaper Rabochaya Tribune, or Worker's Tribune, reported. The Sovietskaya Rossiya story did not specify which days the ``video uprising'' took place but indicated the disturbance had ended recently.

DOC.HEAD: Police Move to Protect Crumbling Berlin Wall
With AM-East Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Tourists have chiseled so many souvenirs out of the Berlin Wall that some sections are in danger of collapsing, and police have had to cordon off one especially hard-hit area near the Brandenburg Gate. The East German government plans eventually to tear down the entire wall and replace it with normal border markings, President Manfred Gerlach disclosed in an interview last week. But free-lance demolition work has already proceeded on the 100-mile border barrier, especially on the West Berlin side. East German border guards on Sunday welded steel bars over a gaping hole near the Brandenburg Gate to shore up the reinforced concrete structure. West Berlin police put up crowd control barriers Saturday around the most damaged sections to keep adults and children from climbing inside giant holes carved out of a double-walled segment. Police cited a danger of collapse. Once covered by graffiti, the wall has been chipped bare at the Brandenburg Gate, the 18th-century arch that now symbolizes German unity. The wall has also taken a beating at Checkpoint Charlie, the famed intra-Berlin crossing, but police said they do not fear a collapse there. On Sunday, onlookers and chippers on the West Berlin side booed when East German border guards welded steel bars over a 7-foot-high hole at the Reichstag, the former seat of Germany's parliament near the Brandenburg Gate. Enterprising vendors have been selling pieces of the wall for up $30 and even rent hammers and chisels for do-it-yourself chipping. But each wall chunk removed means lost business for East Germany. An East German company said last month it plans to raise Western currency by selling sections of the wall removed from the Brandenburg Gate and Potsdamer Platz, a square that was the hub of 1920s Berlin. Profits from sales are to go to humanitarian causes. Communist East German authorities have punched dozens of crossings into the wall since their decision Nov. 9 to open borders to the West, The action was the result of a sudden and peaceful popular revolution that drummed hard-line Communist leaders out of power.

DOC.HEAD: Market Weak on East European Debt
DOC.TEXT: Eastern European governments have fallen in love with free markets, but there's at least one free market that doesn't love them. The more democratic governments that have taken over from the hard-line communists in Eastern Europe are still liable for the debts incurred primarily during the 1970s when Western bankers thought the Soviet bloc was a good credit risk. But there is waning hope among Western financial dealers that the loans will ever be paid in full, even as Western governments are seeking ways to support the democracy movement so that Western bankers and businesses will invest in Eastern Europe. Western bankers fear the new Eastern European governments will set their sights more on internal development programs and less on paying off old debts. The old debts of Poland and some other Eastern European countries are bought on the so-called secondary market by speculators who want to collect the interest still paid on them by the borrowers. Speculators also hope that they can sell the debt at a higher price or that some day the debtor government will pay in full. Last July Polish debt was selling for as much as 41 cents on the dollar of the debt's original value. But Friday Polish debt was selling at just 17.5 cents on the dollar, and the debts of Hungary and Bulgaria have started to show signs of weakness. The debt of Yugoslavia, a communist-ruled country outside the Soviet bloc, has been sharply devalued. Keith Fogarty, managing director of Dillon, Read International Finance, estimated that Poland owes $6 billion to $7 billion to private creditors in other countries. For the past few years these debts have been trading on the secondary market at 35 cents to 45 cents on the dollar. ``Then last fall the Poles sent out a telex saying they could not pay the full interest anymore _ only about 15 percent of it,'' Fogarty said in an interview. The Poles said they pay the remainder of the interest later, but financial markets are dubious. Fogarty said Poland has many other pressing needs for the hard foreign currency _ yen, dollars or West German marks _ in which the interest must be paid. But it has few ways to earn that money. It needs foreign currency, for example, to buy equipment for farms that have been much neglected. Partly as a result of that neglect, it has little food to sell. The United States and Western Europe are sending relief shipments. Other experts point out that the new Polish government, the first non-communist authority in Eastern Europe in 40 years, is led by people who were active in the Solidarity trade union. They would not want to be seen paying out large sums to financiers at a time when workers are being thrown out of jobs and paying high prices for necessities. For their parts, the new governments in Poland and other countries are eagerly freeing the prices of goods from traditional communist controls and letting them find their own level on the market. The new governments hope the inevitable price rises will bring more supplies. That would ease the equally traditional communist scarcity of food and other basic products. The price of a loaf of bread in Poland, which has taken the lead in opening up to the market, has just gone up from the equivalent of 9 cents to 14 cents. Most of the Polish and other East European debt being traded was money lent by private banks in West Germany, France and Japan, with a small share from American bankers. Many of those bankers believed the Soviet Union ultimately would be responsible for Polish debt, but in the early 1980s Moscow made it plain that it would not. The Central Intelligence Agency estimated that the Soviet Union owed $42.3 billion in the West at the end of 1988, about as much as Poland. But Soviet debts are not much traded. Unlike Poland, Yugoslavia and many Third World countries the Soviet Union has always kept up with its payments _ it has vast resources of gold and petroleum that produce hard currency. Yugoslav debt was selling Friday at 52.5 cents on the dollar, according to Dillon, Read. Paul Masco, a trader at Salomon Brothers, said that Yugoslav debt had sold for as little as 40 cents on the dollar. It rose to 57 cents last fall, after the Yugoslav government started a program of buying some of it back in Yugoslav currency at prices advantageous to creditors. Now Yugoslavia is in trouble and the price has fallen again. Masco said Hungarian debt had been trading at par, but recently it fell to 98 cents or 99 cents on the dollar because of the expectation that Hungary will want to borrow a lot more money. There is some doubt about the country's ability to handle a lot of new debt, he added. According to the World Bank, Hungary already owed private creditors more than $13 billion at the end of 1988.

DOC.HEAD: PLO Separates Warring Shiite Factions; Combat Flares Across Green Line
DOC.TEXT: Christian troops and Moslem militiamen battled with mortars and tank fire across Beirut's dividing Green Line for a second day Sunday, while hundreds of PLO guerrillas were deployed to stop militia battles in south Lebanon. No casualties were reported from the fighting in Beirut or the duels between the Iranian-backed Hezbollah, or Party of God, and the pro-Syrian Amal militia in south Lebanon. The violence in Beirut after a three-month lull raised fears of renewed carnage in the 14-year-old civil war. Thousands of Beirut residents scurried to basements and bomb shelters as the thunderous blasts of mortar and artillery shells echoed across the city. Moslem militias entrenched in the Ras el-Nabaa neighborhood accused soldiers of Christian Gen. Michel Aoun of starting the clash. Aoun's command said in a communique that ``Syria's surrogates'' were behind the escalation. Green Line fighting on Saturday killed two Christian civilians and wounded two Moslems. The clashes also forced the closing of the only gateway between the Moslem and Christian sectors of the capital. Police said it was the gravest violation of a cease-fire called by the Arab League on Sept. 22. That truce halted six months of murderous artillery duels between Aoun's forces and the Syrian army, which Aoun has vowed to drive from Lebanon. ``The accelerating tempo of the violations is alarming,'' said a police spokesman, who cannot be named in line with standing rules. ``There is no cohesive mechanism to curb the breaches.'' The hostilities reflect a deepening political crisis resulting from Aoun's defiance of the government of President Elias Hrawi, elected by parliament Nov. 24. Hrawi was elected as part of an Arab League peace plan that Aoun refused to accept. He opposed the plan because it did not include a deadline for the withdrawal of Syria's 40,000 troops from Lebanon. Also at war are Amal and Hezbollah, Shiite Moslem militias who have been battling two years for domination of Lebanon's 1.2 million Shiites. Iran's deputy foreign minister, Mohammad Ali Besharati, arrived in the Syrian capital Saturday, seeking a settlement to the latest round of fighting, which has killed at least 77 people and wounded 275 wounded since Dec. 23. The PLO sent in 400 guerrillas Sunday to reinforce a 300-strong force dispatched last week to separate Amal and Hezbollah fighters, police said. The PLO guerrillas fanned out in a two-mile buffer zone between Hezbollah's front lines in the village of Kfar Milki and Amal's forces in the adjacent village of Kfar Hatta, police reported. The guerrillas, equipped with jeep-mounted anti-aircraft guns and shoulder-fired armor piercing rockets, ignored warning shots from Hezbollah fighters and set up checkpoints 20 yards from the entrance to each village. Both sides had been pounding each other with rockets and other artillery but stopped after the guerrillas moved in. Police said the PLO apparently is seeking to prevent either Shiite faction from capturing territory that would give it direct access to the Palestinian refugee camps of Ein el-Hilweh and Mieh Mieh. The camps are PLO chairman Yasser Arafat's main strongholds in Lebanon.

DOC.HEAD: Liberian Refugees Report Troops Attacking Civilians
DOC.TEXT: Liberians are fleeing across the border to the Ivory Coast to escape violence resulting from an alleged coup attempt, and they accuse the military of killing civilians indiscriminately, it was reported Sunday. On Saturday, President Samuel K. Doe warned Liberians to ``be on the safe side'' and turn in suspected rebels. The British Broadcasting Corp. said Sunday that Liberian refugees who crossed into neighboring Ivory Coast claim soldiers have opened fire on civilians and killed an unknown number. It is difficult to determine the number of Liberians fleeing because the border area is heavily forested and communications are poor. Some reports have put the figure as high as 8,000 to 10,000. The sparsely populated region 100 miles northeast of Monrovia, the capital, was placed under a dusk-to-dawn curfew. Fighting erupted two weeks ago when Liberia claims about 100 rebels led by a former Liberian civil servant crossed into northeastern Nimba County from Ivory Coast to overthrow Doe. Doe told thousands at a rally in Monrovia on Saturday that Liberian forces were engaged in a massive search to find remaining rebels. He ordered citizens to inform on the rebels' whereabouts, ``because if we catch them in your home, we will treat you as a rebel. Therefore, furnish us with information if you want to be on the safe side.'' Liberia said the rebels, who call themselves the National Patriotic Front, killed more than 200 people but that troops were bringing the situation under control and only a few of the dissidents remained at large. Brig. Gen. Edward Smith, army commander in the embattled Nimba county, was quoted on the radio as saying that in one border town, rebels shot to death seven people as they were praying in a mosque. Smith also said three identity cards taken from suspected rebels identified the rebels as being from Ivory Coast. Liberia repeatedly has accused Ivory Coast of harboring Doe's opponents, a charge the Ivorians deny. Ivory Coast President Felix Houphouet-Boigny reportedly sent a high-level delegation to Danande, the Ivorian border village from where the dissidents are said to have crossed into Liberia. In Paris, the humanitarian organization Doctors Without Borders said an evaluation team that flew to the Ivory Coast on Friday found ``a precarious nutritional situation among the Liberian refugees,'' most of whom were women, children or elderly people. ``The number of wounded people arriving in the Ivory Coast is not very great for the moment,'' the organization said in a statement. A second three-member team, carrying emergency medical gear, was being dispatched Sunday night from Paris to Abidjan, the Ivory Coast capital, the group said. The dissidents are led by Charles Taylor, a Liberian government official from 1980-83. Taylor was accused of embezzling nearly $1 million and fled to the United States, where he was imprisoned pending extradition. He escaped in 1984. His forces appear to have no connection with Liberia's opposition parties. Doe, a former sergeant major, seized power in an April 1980 coup in which President William Tolbert and most of his political allies were killed.

DOC.HEAD: Student Charged With Creating Computer Worm Goes on Trial
DOC.TEXT: A graduate student charged with crippling a national computer network goes to court this week, and win or lose, his showcase federal trial will mean more stringent computer security laws, say industry experts. Robert T. Morris Jr., 24, of Arnold, Md., a graduate student suspended from Cornell University, is the first person to be tried criminally under the 1986 federal Computer Fraud and Abuse Act. Jury selection begins Monday. Morris is accused of designing and setting loose in November 1988 a rogue program that replicated wildly, immobilizing an estimated 6,000 computers linked to a research network, including computers at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration facility at Moffet Field, Calif., and at the Air Force Logistics Command at Wright Patterson Air Force Base in Dayton, Ohio. The program was originally described as a computer ``virus,'' but experts said it was more properly called a ``worm,'' which unlike a virus does not need to be in a host program to duplicate itself. Morris, a first-year doctoral student in computer studies, has never admitted creating the worm or introducing it into the Internet system. But a Cornell commission concluded Morris created the program and was guilty of ``reckless disregard'' in doing so. Morris, whose father is chief scientist at the government's National Computer Security Center in Bethesda, Md., faces up to five years in prison and a $250,000 fine if convicted. ``It's a no-lose situation because the trial will showcase the weaknesses of computer security and current computer security law,'' said Harold Highland, professor emeritus of computer science at the State University of New York and editor of Computers & Security, a trade journal. If the government loses, he said, computer security advocates ``will say there is a need for stronger laws. If the government wins, they'll say he did it because the system is weak and we need to tighten up the system.'' Christopher A. Breceda of American Computer Security Industries Inc., a Nashville, Tenn., maker of security systems, agreed. ``Either way it goes, the pure attention is going to fuel the cry for tougher laws and better security,'' he said. ``Whether Morris is convicted or not, we win.'' The 3-year-old federal law makes it a felony to ``intentionally access a federal interest computer without authorization and alter, destroy or damage information'' or ``prevent access'' to such computers. The law applies only to U.S. government computers, computers of financial institutions and networks covering more than one state. Joseph B. Tompkins Jr., chairman of the American Bar Association's Task Force on Computer Crime, is one of numerous computer crime specialists who have appeared before Congress to urge passage of an even stronger law. In November, Tompkins told a House Judiciary subcommittee the statute is unclear about whether a hacker can claim he didn't have malicious intent and that it was an innocent prank or a demonstration of weaknesses in computer security. Morris' attorney, Thomas Guidoboni, raised the question of intent in a motion seeking dismissal of the indictment. U.S. District Judge Howard Munson rejected the request. It is expected that Guidoboni will focus on intent as Morris' defense. Several associates have said that Morris created the worm to call attention to the security shortcomings of the Internet system but that the program ran amok. Eugene Spafford, a professor of computer science at Purdue University who has written articles on the Morris case and a book on computer viruses, said that the lack of intent to damage should not be a defense. ``Ten years ago, these kinds of things didn't hurt anybody, but you have to realize now all the places where computers are used and the dangers involved in shutting down a system or damaging data,'' said Spafford, who is expected to be a government witness. ``There's only a subtle difference between this and a person who burns down a building and says he didn't mean to do it and says, `It just got away from me.''' Spafford said computer crime losses in the United States total about $7 billion annually. The worm allegedly created by Morris did not destroy any data, and prosecutors have not put a price tag on the damage. But Spafford estimated the one-day paralysis cost between $5 million and $15 million in lost time and in later protective work. Spafford also said he believes the case will focus attention on computer security, but he doesn't think it is going to affect a public perception that such crimes aren't serious. ``There is a kind of sympathy for the hacker. He's seen as a bored college student or a brillant college student exposing a weakness or striking a blow against the system,'' said Spafford. ``Nevertheless, all the inconvenience and damage that is caused fits what I'd call vandalism.''

DOC.HEAD: Dukakis The Target In Governor's Race
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis will be the issue in this year's race for governor even though the unpopular Democrat won't even be on the ballot. Dukakis' popularity took a nosedive after he returned from his unsuccessful bid for president in 1988 to a state in its worst financial crisis since the mid-1970s. Its bonds are ranked lowest in the nation by one rating agency. Even former Attorney General Francis Bellotti, a Democrat who backed Dukakis for the presidency and has been a fixture in state politics, is running as a self-styled ``outsider.'' With the party primaries still more than eight months away, the Democratic race also includes Lt. Gov. Evelyn Murphy and Rep. John Flood of Canton, a Dukakis critic. Boston University President John Silber and Boston Mayor Raymond Flynn are considering the Democratic race. U.S. Rep. Joseph Kennedy has taken himself out of it. The Republican field is led by former federal prosecutor William Weld and state House Minority Leader Steven Pierce. It also includes former Rep. Paul Cronin and former Metropolitan District Commissioner Guy Carbone. The fields will probably be narrowed during state political conventions, in March for Republicans and June for the Democrats. Both parties require candidates to get the support of at least 15 percent of the convention delegates to win a spot in the Sept. 18 primaries. Dukakis took himself out of the governor's race a year ago, setting the stage for a wide-open election that Republicans say could be their best chance of recapturing an office they have not held since 1974. That was the year Dukakis defeated Republican incumbent Frank Sargent. Except for a four-year absence after he was defeated by Democrat Edward J. King in a primary in 1978, Dukakis has been governor since. Pierce says the state's fiscal mess _ with the budget deficit still calculated at about $500 million even after a series of sharp cuts in state spending _ and the failure of Dukakis and the Democratic-controlled Legislature to solve it will be a focus in the GOP nomination for governor. ``That asbolutely presents us with our best political opportunity in many years,'' said Pierce, who brought up the issue of rising state spending and sinking revenues while Dukakis was running against George Bush. Weld announced his bid for the Republican nomination last week. ``In 1990, the people of the commonwealth are saying that they are ready for a change, ready to move beyond the big government philosophy that has brought us to the brink of fiscal ruin,'' Weld said. Pierce is a veteran legislator, while Weld lost his one bid for statewide office, an attorney general's race against Bellotti in 1978. He then made a reputation for fighting public corruption as U.S. attorney for Massachusetts. Republicans are not alone in calling for change. Bellotti, who served as attorney general for 12 years before stepping down in 1986, called on voters to ``take back the state'' from ``technocrats and team players'' in his announcement. ``I have spent my career threatening the status quo and running as an outsider,'' Bellotti said, who has run for governor twice before. Flood, House chairman of the Legislature's Taxation Committee, also sounded an outsider theme when he announced his candidacy in October. ``There are those who say a Democrat cannot win next year's election for governor of the commonwealth. That will not be the case if our party embraces new ideas, new directions and, most important, new leadership for the '90s,'' Flood said. Even Murphy, the ``team player'' Bellotti referred to, has advocated tougher fiscal management than Dukakis. Murphy, however, has been the only candidate to join Dukakis in calling for higher taxes to balance the state's budget and has campaigned for support among traditional Democratic interest groups such as public employee unions. Before becoming lieutenant governor, Murphy served in Dukakis administrations as secretary of environmental affairs and as economic development secretary. Silber, a transplanted Texan considered conservative by Massachusetts Democratic standards, could become the ultimate outsider candidate, although he is looking for support from some traditional Democratic powers. They include state Senate President William Bulger and former Boston Mayor Kevin White, now a BU faculty member. Flynn may be inching closer to seeking the Democratic nomination, saying recently that he is willing to ``lay it on the line'' if the Legislature fails to raise taxes to save social programs and aid to local government. Flynn, while potentially appealing to liberals on most social issues, opposes abortion, a position that could give him trouble in a state that polls show is solidly pro-choice.

DOC.HEAD: Mohtashemi on Hostages, Gulf Relations, Economic Investment
DOC.TEXT: Iranian Parliament member Ali Akbar Mohtashemi said in an interview released Sunday that Iran does not want ties with the United States and that the Lebanese have a right to hold foreign hostages. In the interview with the English-language Tehran Times, the former Iranian foreign minister said Iran is interested in developing diplomatic relations with all the countries of the world except the United States, Israel and South Africa. Mohtashemi said the holding of foreign hostages in Lebanon was an internal matter and he believes the Lebanese are within their rights. ``Lebanese Sunnis, Shiites, Druse and Christians are the hostages of the U.S., Israel and other Western powers,'' Mohtashemi said. ``So it's their natural right to take hostages to inflict heavy blows on their enemies.'' ``No negotiations, but force is the answer to what the enemies of the Lebanese have done against that deprived nation,'' he said. The 18 foreigners held hostage in Lebanon are believed held by Shiite Moslem groups loyal to Iran. The hostages include eight Americans, among them Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press. Anderson was kidnapped March 16, 1985, and is the longest-held hostage. An advance copy of Mothashemi's interview was telexed to The Associated Press in Nicosia by the newspaper. President Hashemi Rafsanjani ousted Mohtashemi as interior minister after his election last July. Mohtashemi, a leader of a radical group of clergy, was elected to Parliament in a by-election last month. Before becoming interior minister in 1984, he was ambassador to Syria and was credited with creating Hezbollah, or Party of God, the fundamentalist Lebanese Shiite militia believed to be the umbrella for the groups holding hostages. The mothers of two Swiss relief workers who were taken hostage in Lebanon four months ago arrived in Beirut on Sunday with a petition signed by 70,000 people urging the men's release. Emmanuel Christen and Elio Erriquez worked as orthopedic technicians at a Red Cross clinic in south Lebanon that provided artificial limbs to Lebanese and Palestinian war victims. No group has claimed responsibility for kidnapping Christen, 32, and Erriquez, 23. The PLO and Lebanese police contend the pair are held by the Fatah Revolutionary Council, a breakaway guerrilla group led by Palestinian terrorist mastermind Abu Nidal. The group has denied responsibility. ``I cannot be pessimistic in thinking of my son's release. I should always be optimistic,'' Marianne Christen told reporters upon arrival at Beirut airport. She and Graziella Erriquez planned to hold a news conference in Beirut on Monday and return to Geneva on Tuesday. On Saudi Arabia, Mohtashemi said that close ties were blocked by what he called the kingdom's suppression of Iranian-led demonstrations during the 1987 pilgrimage to Mecca. More than 400 demonstrators, mostly Iranians, died in ensuing violence, and last year Saudi Arabia executed 16 Kuwaiti Shiites it said confessed to planting bombs that killed one pilgrim. The two events ``bar any Moslem country from having relations with such a foreign-dependent country,'' Mohtashemi said. He said relations with Syria would remain strong and not be changed by the recent restoration of links between Syria and Egypt. Syria was Iran's staunchest ally during the Iran-Iraq war, and Egypt backed Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Troops Kill Gunman on Jordanian Border
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with Jordan comment, official saying gunman may be responsible for all five attacks; Picks up 5th graf, `Israel's chief ...'
DOC.TEXT: Soldiers killed an armed infiltrator from Jordan near an Israeli tourist resort Sunday in the fifth shooting this year along the countries' border, an army spokesman said. Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin issued a tough statement on behalf of the government, saying Israel regards Jordan as fully responsible for any border infiltrations. The army spokesman said troops opened fire on a gunman wearing a Jordanian army uniform near the Hamat Gader sulpher springs park, five miles east of the Sea of Galilee. The spokesman, who under military regulations was not identified, said the gunman was carrying a U.S.-made M-16 assault rifle, standard equipment in the Jordanian army. No Israeli soldiers were reported wounded. The gunman carried nine clips of ammunition, four of which were empty, the spokesman said, adding that he believed it was likely that the lone gunman was responsible for all five shooting incidents this year. In Jordan, an army official said a conscript from the same area ``was absent since yesterday and had his personal weapon.'' The official, quoted by the state-run Petra news agency, said soldiers had searched the area but could not find him. Israel's chief of staff, Lt. Gen. Dan Shomron, told army radio that the infiltration may have been carried out by Palestinian guerrillas that crossed from a third country into Jordan to attack Israelis along the border. But he also said that the recent spate of attacks could have been carried out by Jordanian soldiers encouraged by the recent success of Islamic fundamentalists in Jordan's parliamentary elections. On Friday, Israeli troops patrolling in the same area came under fire twice. Afterward, the army evacuated dozens of tourists who had been bathing in the springs or fishing. Israel radio reported that radical Palestinians led by Abu Musa, a Syrian-backed dissident from the PLO, claimed responsibility for the attack. A similar incident occurred in the Hamat Gader area Monday. On Thursday, Israeli soldiers opened fire on two men who appeared to be attempting to infiltrate from Jordan about six miles south of the Sea of Galilee, and one of the would-be infiltrators was wounded, the army said. In a statement released before the gunman was killed Sunday, Rabin said: ``Israel views the government of Jordan as responsible for the prevention of hostile acts against the territory of Israel.'' Rabin said the ``army is increasing its activities to prevent shooting and the infiltration of terrorist squads from the territory of Jordan into Israel.'' The statement was released after a Cabinet discussion on the shooting incidents. In Jordan, Foreign Minister Marwan el-Kassem said Israel is responsible for the shooting incidents and that Jordan has no desire to increase tensions along the border, Israel's army radio reported. He spoke prior to the fatal shooting. Last year, there were seven incidents along the Jordanian border, including six infiltrations, the army said. Three Israeli soldiers were killed and at least seven soldiers and civilians wounded in the 1989 incidents, the army said.

DOC.HEAD: Six Visas Approved For U.S. Diplomats
DOC.TEXT: The leftist Sandinista government has approved six entry visas for American diplomats to allow the minimum number of officers at the U.S. Embassy, an official source said Sunday. Twenty U.S. diplomats were expelled from Nicaragua on Dec. 29 in retaliation for a raid by U.S. troops on the Nicaraguan ambassador's residence in Panama City. Nine U.S. diplomats were left in place, including Charge d'Affaires John Leonard. Under international conventions, the minimum number of diplomats in a foreign mission is 15. The Nicaraguan Foreign Ministry source, who insisted on anonymity, said the six American diplomats were expected to arrive soon. Leonard has been the chief U.S. diplomat in Managua since July 1988, when the Nicaraguan government expelled U.S. Ambassador Richard Melton and seven other American diplomats, accusing them of inciting anti-government demonstrations. Washington retaliated by expelling the same number of Nicaraguan diplomats, including Ambassador Carlos Tunnermann. In May 1989, Nicaragua expelled two U.S. diplomats, including one based in Honduras who was on a working visit here, also accusing them of inciting unrest. Washington again retaliated in kind.

DOC.HEAD: Noriega Was Warned He Risked Same End as Mussolini
DOC.TEXT: Panama's Gen. Manuel Noriega decided to give himself up after an aide warned he risked the same end as Italy's fascist dictator, Benito Mussolini, the papal nuncio in Panama was quoted Sunday as saying. Monsignor Jose Sabastian Laboa, the Vatican's representative in Panama, said Capt. Eliecer Gaitan, Noriega's personal security chief, helped persuade Noriega to leave the Vatican Embassy, newspapers reported. Gaitan told Noriega they risked the same fate as Mussolini because Panamanians would one day storm the embassy, Laboa was quoted as telling Italian journalists in Panama. Mussolini was shot and killed and then hanged by his feet in a public square. Laboa has insisted that Noriega left the embassy on his own accord and previously denied reports he gave Noriega an ultimatum to leave the mission. Laboa said there was never any talk of granting concessions and that once it was made clear Noriega would not be sent to another country, it came down to getting him to accept guarantees such as not facing the death penalty in the United States. ``He knows Panamanian prisons, while I told him those in America have TV and air conditioning,'' the nuncio was quoted as saying in Turin's La Stampa and other newspapers. Laboa said it was his decision to allow Noriega in the embassy Dec. 24 and that he did not have time to consult with the Vatican. ``I asked help from the Lord and understood that the most important thing was to avoid further combat and that, if Noriega entered the embassy, the battle was over,'' the nuncio was quoted as saying. Noriega took refuge in the embassy four days after U.S. troops invaded Panama in an effort to capture him and bring him to the United States to face drug charges. Noriega left the embassy Jan. 3 and was taken to Miami to face charges.

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: Whoopie-ie-oh! Get along little crawfish! The ranch foreman shaded his eyes from the Florida Panhandle sun with a rakish cowboy hat, grinned broadly and recounted tales from the crawfish corral. ``Crawfish are easier to round up than cattle are,'' said M-K Ranch foreman Bryant Copeland, in his native Arkansas drawl. ``Harder to brand, but easier to round up.'' Copeland allowed how he was only kidding about the branding, but not the roundups at the M-K ranches. They are done with 40 flat-bottom boats built in Louisiana bayou country where crawfish, which look like small lobsters, are a staple of the Cajun diet. Until five years ago, Copeland had never eaten one of the freshwater crustaceans. Now, he supervises one of the largest crawfish-raising operations in the nation. Each year, M-K Ranches produce from 850,000 to 1 million pounds of crawfish, also known as crayfish or ``mud bugs.'' The switch to aquaculture meant some retraining for hands at the ranch that had once raised cattle, but Copeland said it's all the same. ``Farming is farming,'' Copeland said. ``It's 24 hours a day, seven days a week.''

DOC.HEAD: Iranian Deputy Tells Soviet Demonstrators that Border Protests Fruitless
DOC.TEXT: An Iranian legislator shouted to protesters across the Soviet border Sunday that Iran wants closer relations with them but that border protests are useless, Iran's official news agency reported. About 1,000 demonstraters on the Soviet side of the Araks River, which forms part of the closed border, chanted Islamic slogans for two hours Sunday, the Islamic Republic News Agency said. The report from the border town of Jolfa said a similar group gathered on the Iranian bank of the river and ``responded to the enthusiasm of the Soviet Moslems.'' Soviet protesters in the republic of Azerbaijan are demanding freedom to travel to the Iranian region of the same name. Like Iranians, most residents of Soviet Azerbaijan are Shiite Moslems. Soviet officials expressed concern about Islamic fundamentalism creeping across the border after the Islamic revolution in Iran in 1979. The border protests began Dec. 31, and at one point extra Soviet border guards were deployed to control demonstrators who threatened to dismantle the border barriers. IRNA, monitored in Nicosia, said Karim Shafe'i, representative from the northwest city of Marand in the national Parliament, used a loudspeaker to tell Soviets the Iranian people want closer relations. But he called on them to ``safeguard the security of the border lines,'' the report said. It quoted him as saying the protests on the riverbank were ``fruitless and that Soviet Moslems can talk to their officials to prepare the grounds for visiting Iran.'' Another IRNA report quoted demonstraters as threatening to build a bridge across the river with their own hands if their demands for freer travel were not met. It said the demonstraters were demanding the government fulfill promises made six months ago for freer travel to Iran, especially to visit religious shrines. Tehran radio, also monitored in Nicosia, reported that three Soviet Moslems crossed into Iran's Azerbaijan over the weekend and returned home after a daylong visit carrying souvenirs and copies of the Koran, Islam's holy book. The broadcast said the Soviet Azerbaijanis crossed the Araks River and visited Iranian Moslems in the village of Poldasht on Saturday. It did not say if the men swam the river or used boats. Four Soviet youths cut through wire border fences on the river and swam to the Iranian side a week ago. A fifth companion drowned. Tass, the official Soviet news agency, said protesters have destroyed guard observation towers, electronic alarm equipment and communications lines along the border since the unrest began. It said one person was killed in a clash among protesters but did not give details. The Iranian broadcast coincided with a report on Moscow radio that the Azerbaijani government has promised to allow more access to arable land on the banks of the Araks River and take measures to make it easier to cross the border into Iran. Soviet Azerbaijan was acquired by Russia in the 1800s. In 1941, the Red Army moved into northern Iran and the Soviets set up a puppet state there. But after an international outcry, the troops pulled out in 1946.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Soldier Emerges After 42 Years in Woods, Media Say
LaserPhoto NY15
DOC.TEXT: A soldier who claims he went into hiding from Stalin's secret police 42 years ago has emerged from the woods, convinced by reports of the Kremlin's reforms that it is finally safe, Soviet media reported Sunday. Ivan Bushilo was a 25-year-old decorated veteran newly returned home when he ran afoul of Josef Stalin's secret police in 1947, Soviet TV reported in footage showing the wrinkled but healthy-looking 68-year-old adjusting to life in his home village in Byelorussia. When his attempts to fight the injustices of the security police put him in serious danger, Bushilo fled to the Byelorussian woods and lived off the land in primitive shelters for the next four decades, Soviet TV said. He had almost no human contact except for rare visits from close relatives, the official news agency Tass reported. None of the reports explained how Bushilo could have survived the cold winters, and they did not say if Soviet officials believed Bushilo's tale. In an interview with the weekly news program Seven Days, Bushilo said it was reports about President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in newspapers he was brought that persuaded him to come back. Asked why he didn't return earlier, Bushilo said, ``I didn't come out because I didn't trust anybody. Only now I trust Gorbachev. And only Gorbachev.'' Bushilo said he was never sick throughout all those years in the woods. He survived without a gun, mainly by trapping and fishing and gathering what the forest would yield. Relatives brought him occasional clothes, food and newspapers, Tass said. Bushilo told Soviet TV it was knowing he was right that gave him the strength to survive. ``My truth gave me all the strength I needed,'' the former peasant said. ``I am not a criminal. I was not hiding from justice, for some crime, but for the truth.''

DOC.HEAD: Noriega Ouster Blow For Castro
With AM-US-Panama, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The overthrow of Panamanian Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega not only rid the United States of a nettlesome regime in this hemisphere, but dealt a blow to the nemesis at its back door, Cuba's Castro government, observers say. ``There are many impacts for Castro,'' said Jamie Suchlicki, director of the Institute of Interamerican Studies at University of Miami. ``Noriega was an ally of Fidel, so he lost a friend. More importantly, he lost a place where he could do business.'' Some ever-hopeful Cuban exiles saw the U.S. invasion and Noreiga's surrender as a step toward bringing down Castro's 31-year-old government. ``The people in Cuba have to be free _ maybe in six months, no later than one year,'' said Norberto Pino, part of the crowd that turned out at the federal courthouse Thursday for Noriega's arraignment on drug charges. ``Rent This Ad When Fidel Falls,'' read a banner pulled by a small plane flying over the courthouse. Sen. Bob Graham, D-Fla., noted that the ouster of Noriega followed the falls of one-party governments in the East bloc, Castro's cooled relations with reform-minded Moscow, and the rise of elected governments in Latin America. ``With the downfall of yet another dictator, Castro will seem even more like a relic _ out of step with the times and out of touch with reality,'' Graham said. Panama's new leader, President Guillermo Endara, has said his government will study the question of Panama's relations with Cuba, but has other priorities now. But few Cuba-watchers expect Castro to have keep the advantages he had when Noriega ruled Panama. While Suchlicki said Castro is firmly in control of his own country, he and others identified a variety of likely effects on Castro of the ouster of Noriega, including: _ Loss of a conduit for technology and a range of U.S.-produced equipment and commodities banned from Cuba because of the U.S. trade embargo. The U.S. Customs Service, indicting three men in 1987 for violating the U.S. trade embargo with Cuba on selling computer equipment, said the Cuban Minister of Commerce had set up several ``front companies'' in Panama to get around the embargo. Castro has denied Noriega cooperated with Cuba in smuggling technology. But even common items were getting from the United States to Cuba via Panama, authorities say. _ Potential embarrassment for Castro during Noriega's trial. The Miami federal indictment alleges that Castro acted as a mediator in a 1984 dispute between Noriega and the Medellin Cartel cocaine traffickers he was supposed to be protecting in Panama. There are no details cited in the indictment, and prosecutors said in 1988 they lacked evidence to indict Castro along with Noriega. However, some of the government's key witnesses have claimed first-hand knowledge of Castro's involvement. Castro denies that he supports drug trafficking. U.S. investigators have charged for years, including in a 1982 federal indictment in Miami of four Cuban officials who were never prosecuted, that Castro has allowed Cuba to be used for trafficking to the United States. _ Reduced intelligence-gathering. ``Castro's embassy in Panama was a major intelligence-gathering center,'' said Ambler Moss, former U.S. ambassador to Panama. _ The loss of another friendly government in this region. Since 1979, when pro-Castro governments came to power in Nicaragua and Grenada, Cuba has seen Jamaica's Michael Manley government defeated in 1980 elections (Manley at the time blamed the United States, but won elections last year after promising a moderate government that will seek cooperation with Washington), Grenada's Marxist government fall in a 1983 rift capped by the U.S. invasion, Suriname sever most ties with Cuba in 1983, and general decreased influence for leftist parties throughout the Caribbean. Castro condemned the U.S. invasion of Panama and Moss, now dean of the Graduate School of International Studies at University of Miami, said Castro is using the invasion ``as a distracting issue'' at home. Cuba's economy is stagnant, and reduced trade with East bloc countries and, potentially, reduced aid from the Soviet Union will worsen the economy and could stimulate domestic opposition, the observers said. ``Fidel seems to be still strong and charismatic. Fidel is also ruthless,'' Suchlicki said. ``I don't think the thing is ripe yet,'' he said. ``But after what we've seen (in Eastern Europe), I hate to be categoric about anything.''

DOC.HEAD: More Indian Art Works Discovered Missing From LA Museum
DOC.TEXT: Forty-four more pieces of valuable American Indian art have been reported missing from the Southwest Museum, bringing the institution's total loss to more than $2 million, officials said. Among the latest items discovered missing are a personally inscribed Thomas Moran painting that could fetch more than $100,000 at auction and a sacred Zuni wood carving, museum officials said. Other items include masks, paintings, baskets, carvings and jewelry. Museum officials intitially reported 65 items missing. The FBI has recovered eight of those pieces and has leads on 16 others, Southwest Museum Executive Director Jerome Selmer said in a recent interview. ``We get the feeling that things are picking up in the investigation, that more pieces will be recovered soon,'' Selmer said. ``But we are not working under the illusion that we are going to get every piece back.'' Museum officials first became aware art works were missing nine months ago during an inventory that is continuing of the museum's 200,000 items. They declined to discuss how the artworks might have left the museum's collection.

DOC.HEAD: Romanian Minister Calls For More U.S. Assistance
With AM-Romania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The foreign minister believes the U.S. government should be playing a greater role in helping Romania recover from its pro-democracy revolution, a human rights activist said Sunday. Geri Laber, executive director of the U.S.-based Helsinki Watch Human Rights organization, also said human rights groups must ensure that loyalists of former ruler Nicolae Ceausescu receive fair trials and that laws are drafted to replace the draconian ones the Communist dictator relied on for 24 years. Foreign Minister Sergiu Celac told visiting Helsinki Watch representatives he was ``very disappointed that the United States government was so slow in responding to the situation in Romania,'' Laber said. Celac indicated that the nation needs a ``counterbalance'' to an expanded Soviet presence, following a visit Saturday by Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze, according to Laber. Under Ceausescu, the Soviet bloc maverick who frequently acted independently of Moscow, the Soviets had fairly little say in Romanian affairs. Shevardnadze said his country supported ``the solidarity of the Soviet and Romanian peoples'' and pledged ``wide-ranging assistance,'' including immediate supplies of sorely needed oil and gas. Several senior Western government officials also have visited Bucharest since Ceausescu's overthrow Dec. 22. French Premier Roland Dumas and West German Foreign Minister Hans Dietrich Genscher are scheduled to arrive this month. But despite considerable food and medical assistance from the United States, Rep. Frank Wolf, R-Va., has been the highest-ranking U.S. official to visit so far. Laber said, ``As soon as I get back to the U.S., I intend to pressure the State Department into moving quickly on indicating unequivocally its concern for developments in Romania.'' On another matter, Laber said Helsinki Watch was ``very critical of the way Ceausescu and his wife Elena were executed. Although we deplore their crimes, we feel they should have been given a fair hearing, with the right to bring witnesses and present evidence'' in their defense. The two were executed Dec. 25 by firing squad immediately after being tried in secret by a military court. ``Because this happened it is even more incumbent on the government to ensure that the (arrested secret police officers) are accorded fair trials,'' and the Helsinki group plans to send observers to monitor them, Laber said.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Pop superstar Michael Jackson threw a party for 80 abused or neglected children at his 3,000-acre ranch. Jackson greeted the two busloads of children from the Village of Childhelp in Beaumont and gave them a tour of his well-stocked game and toy rooms, and served up a barbecue lunch of hamburgers and hotdogs under sunny blue skies. ``I'm so happy you came and glad you can share all these pleasures with me,'' Jackson told the kids at lunch Saturday, accompanied by his pet chimpanzees Max and Alexandria dressed in blue coveralls and striped T-shirts. The party was private and the singer's comments to the children were relayed through publicist Lee Solters. The kids also got to play volleyball and bounce on a trampoline. The toy room offered an enormous accumulation of playthings Jackson purchased on his recent 17-month world tour. After lunch, Jackson and the kids retired to the ranch's theater to watch the current hit movies ``The Little Mermaid'' and ``Back to the Future Part II.'' The children autographed a lifesize cutout of Jackson and presented it to the singer. ``He's getting a big kick. He's like the Pied Piper,'' the singer's spokesman said.

Pat Sajak made his name and his millions as host of ``Wheel of Fortune,'' but it was another game show that helped prod him toward his second marriage. Sajak was married New Year's Eve to Lesly Brown, a 24-year-old model from Maryland whose previous claims to fame were a lingerie-clad pose in Playboy's ``Women of Washington'' and an appearance on ``The Dating Game.'' Their friendship turned to romance in June when Brown got her Dating Game prize: a chaperoned trip to Mexico with a lucky bachelor, the couple told People magazine. ``Frankly, I was a little annoyed at that,'' Sajak said. ``There was definitely borderline jealousy,'' Brown said. ``That was good.'' Their old-fashioned wedding in Annapolis, Md., included praise from the officiating priest for a wife who is silent and keeps a clean house, People reported. ``Lesly swore to keep quiet and clean the toilet every day. I thought he should say a word about Mop & Glo,'' joked Sajak, who also is host of a late-night talk show. Vanna White, the letter-turner on ``Wheel of Fortune'' and one of 150 guests at the wedding, said, ``It's a storybook love story. Pat seems to have been reborn.''

``Glory,'' the Civil War movie starring Matthew Broderick and Morgan Freeman, has passed muster as authentic in its depiction of a regiment of black soldiers. Two Civil War experts who are sticklers for details found only minuscule breaches in the film. Russ Pritchard, a firearms expert at Philadelphia's Civil War Library and Museum, said he and flag collector Stan Smullen found ``extraordinarily minor'' flaws during a preview Friday. History buffs often have complained about the lack of authenticity in the treatment of the Civil War on television and in the movies. ``It's an absolute incredible movie,'' Pritchard said. ``The combat sequences are the best I've seen in a movie about the 19th century,'' he said. ``All the uniforms, the accouterments, the tack on the horses, even what I would call the background props, they're all great.'' Pritchard said he and Smullen each noticed a flaw. In one scene, recruits were issued Enfield rifled muskets, while someone called out the serial number of each weapon. The regiment carried Enfields, Pritchard said, but Enfields had no serial numbers. Smullen pointed out that the regiment's American flags seemed to have had the stars sewn on. During the Civil War, however, stars would have been painted on the flags, he said. ``Glory'' is the saga of the 54th Massachusetts Regiment, the most famous black unit of the Civil War. It is the story of the soldiers' struggle and the regiment's triumph amid the lost battle of Fort Wagner in 1862.

Delores M. Andy was grand marshal of the high strutting Mummers 90th annual New Years Day parade, which not only stepped off five days late, but had never before been presided over by a woman. Carrying a dozen long-stemmed roses, Ms. Andy led the string bands up Broad Street on Saturday. ``This is wonderful,'' she said. ``It's a beautiful day.'' At least 40,000 turned out to see the 12-hour parade that had been canceled Jan. 1 because of high winds. In keeping with the traditional theme song, ``Oh Dem Golden Slippers,'' most of the Mummers wore their gold-painted shoes as they entertained crowds who shouted ``Happy New Year'' with their famous march called a cakewalk. Andy, city recreation commissioner, was substituting as grand marshal for Mayor W. Wilson Goode who was on vacation.

DOC.HEAD: New York State Court of Appeals Hears Child Pornography Case
DOC.TEXT: It's against the law in New York to produce, sell or even mail child pornography. The state's highest court weighs this week whether it's also illegal to possess it. The Court of Appeals will consider the legality of the indictment of William Keyes of Albany on five counts of promoting a sexual performance by a child. The charge centers on Keyes' possession of pornographic magazines and videotapes with such as ``Lolita Colour Special 7'' and ``Wonderboy'' and whether such possession constitutes promoting a sexual performance. The items were found in his home during a police raid in August 1986. He had gotten them from undercover police agents. At the time of his arrest, Keyes was on five years' probation after pleading guilty to promoting a sexual performance by a child. Because of the prior conviction, Keyes could face a maximum of 3{ to 7 years in prison if convicted on each of the new counts. Keyes, 41, has argued that he was wrongly charged with ``promoting'' pornography because he contends he did nothing more than receive the items from an undercover policeman. The prosecutor, George Barber, countered that the decade-old state law under which Keyes was charged defines ``promoting'' as, among other things, ``procuring'' pornographic items. Prosecutors argue that the law indicates that in this case Keyes did ``procure'' the pornography which means he is subject to indictment. According to court briefs, Albany detectives found Keyes' home telephone number on the stall of a movie-viewing booth at a Troy adult bookstore. Next to the number was written ``Young boys wanted.'' Authorities said that phone number, and statements Keyes made to undercover policemen about the best places in Albany to find underage models, will justify the ``promoting a sexual preformance'' charge, even if the high court throws out their argument that even possession is illegal. So far, state courts have been of two minds about the legality of the indictments. State Supreme Court Joseph Harris ruled in Albany in June 1987 that the Legislature intend to punish the creators and distributors of child pornographic materials, not the customers, and he threw out the indictments. In New York, a Supreme Court is a trial court. In November 1987, the midlevel Appellate Division of state Supreme Court ruled unanimously that the indictments were proper. The attorneys who will argue the case before the Court of Appeals, the state's highest court, agree that the question is bigger than Keyes' own legal fate. In his brief before the court, Barber urged the judges to state in their decision that neither the state nor federal constitutions protect the possession of child pornographic materials. Keyes' attorney, Terence Kindlon, said Albany County prosecutors are violating his client's constitutional rights by trying to equate ``promotion'' with ``possession.'' A study of New York's penal law, Kindlon said, shows that the word ``procure'' means to ``go out and get something for someone else.'' Kindlon called Keyes ``a good guy'' who acknowledged his problem with child pornography and was undergoing psychiatric therapy when approached by Albany policemen about receiving pornographic materials. The items were ``crammed into his hands and he was arrested for having them,'' Kindlon said. ``You go to an Alcoholics Anonymous meeting on the hottest day in August and stand outside passing out free beers, somebody's going to drink one,'' he said. ``Our statute does not make simple possession of this stuff unlawful, but they're trying to read into it such a prohibition,'' Kindlon said. ``They're saying the word `procure' means that you can't have it unless you get it _ that the fact you have it proves you got it.'' An attorney for the Manhattan-based Institute for Youth Advocacy filed a friend-of-the-court brief urging the court to uphold Keyes' indictment. The institute is affiliated with Covenant House, which estimates that half the homeless or runaway youths it takes in have been sexually exploited. Barber said 13 states, including Ohio, Illinois, Missouri and Florida, have expressly outlawed the possession of child pornography in the past eight years. The U.S. Supreme Court recently heard oral arguments in a case challenging Ohio's possession law. Keyes, an auto body worker, is described in court papers as about 80 percent disabled as the result of Vietnam War wounds. When he was put on probation after his 1984 conviction, Albany County Court Judge John Clyne told him: ``There is more to this life than the sickening, perverted books you have been enjoying on your own. Read a good novel.''

DOC.HEAD: Gov't to Form Committee to Investigate Tribal Clash
DOC.TEXT: The Sudanese government said Sunday it would form a committee to investigate a clash between Arab and African tribes Dec. 28 which it said left 214 people dead. A Cabinet statement said an unspecified number of Sudanese from the two tribes had been arrested. Although the rebel Sudan People's Liberation Army claims that more than 2,000 southerners of African descent were killed by Arab militias, the statement said only 214 had been killed and 38 wounded. The southern rebels have accused the government of complicity in the massacre. They said 90 southerners were killed in a police station where they sought refuge.
