The clash took place Dec. 28 in the Jabalain area, south of Kosti and about 250 miles south of Khartoum. The statement said a high-level official delegation had traveled to Jabalain and met with representatives of the two tribes. Zubair Mohamed Salih, deputy chairman of the 15-man ruling military council, said a committee will be formed to investigate the tribal clash. The southern rebels are mainly Christians and animists of African descent. They took up arms against the Arab Moslem majority government in the north in 1983 for more autonomy and economic reforms.

DOC.HEAD: Anti-Communists in Emotional March, Students Rally for Reforms
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UDATE with report elections might be delayed; pick up 7th pvs, `They are...' Minor editing thereafter to conform. ADDS 2 grafs with foreign minister disappointed by lack of U.S. involvement. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos BUC1,2
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of anti-Communists marched and prayed Sunday for the martyrs of Romania's bloody revolution, and students rallied in several cities for educational reforms and a greater say in national affairs. Marchers carried white cloth banners with letters in blood-red paint proclaiming, ``The martyrs want liberty and bread.'' They knelt repeatedly on the ice-covered sidewalks during their slow, half-mile procession. At sites of particularly heavy fighting, they halted to chant the Lord's Prayer and cross themselves. Many women wore black scarves, and some demonstrators carried lit funeral tapers. The march was called by the Peasant and Christian Democratic parties to honor those who fell in the battle against loyalist forces of executed Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. The once-banned parties, which have joined forces in preparation for promised elections in April, have warned against a renaissance of the Communist Party, which has been in de facto dissolution since Ceausescu's downfall. The opposition groups also have expressed concern that the April election date is too soon to allow parties other than the provisional government, the National Salvation Front, sufficient time to prepare. The Front's chairman and interim president, Ion Iliescu, said late Saturday they could be postponed, the national Rompres news agency reported. The Peasant and Christian Democratic parties also have accused the Front, which includes several former Communists, of being a front for communism. Those fears were in evidence Sunday. ``They are calling for a new Communist Party,'' said Constantin Dimitrescu, alluding to tentative calls by some Communists to reform as a Democratic Socialist Party. ``We say to that _ the wolf has changed its fur but not its morals.'' Less than two miles away, about 2,500 students met for a rally at the Polytechnical Institute to press for reform of Ceausescu's heavily indoctrinated education system. Students read an 11-point program addressed to Premier Petre Roman, demanding autonomy for universities, more student say in determining the curriculum and postponement of examinations scheduled for Jan. 25. ``We believe the prime minister will listen to our opinions because he, too, is one of us,'' Bogdan Constantinescu, a mechanical engineering student, told the cheering crowd. Roman previously taught hydraulic engineering at a university before his appointment last month as government head. ``We don't want to waste time on subjects such as political economy...(and) Marxism _ instead we should be able to choose the subjects we want to take,'' Constantinescu said. During Ceausescu's 24-year reign, all students were required to take political subjects extolling the virtues of ``scientific socialism.'' Slogans reading ``Freedom to the Students,'' ``No Politics,'' and ``University Autonomy,'' were draped across the rally hall, where Constantinescu announced the formation of a free students trade union. It will press student demands within Romania's newly established free trade union federation. Razvan Rusovici, a 21-year-old aeronautical engineering student, expressed hope for the future. ``We want to be more like our Western brothers and study what we really need and not what some ignorant dictator imagines we need,'' he said. Thousands of other students held gatherings in Braila and Galatia, about 120 miles northeast of the capital, and in Timisoara, the cradle of the revolution, about 300 miles northwest of Bucharest. Nicolae Costel, an official of the Christian Democratic Party, described the pro-democracy demonstrations as among the most widespread since Ceausescu's overthrow Dec. 22 and execution three days later. Costel said in an interview that the rallies outside Bucharest were called to demand greater student representation on the National Salvation Front. The Front has decided to run on a democratic platform in the elections, despite initially saying it would not field candidates. Sunday's newspapers continued attempts to determine what happened to the bodies of hundreds of protesters believed killed Dec. 16-17 by pro-Ceausescu armed units in Timisoara, site of the first major demonstrations against Ceausescu. Romania Libera, in an article headlined ``Where are the dead people from Timisoara?'' said most of the bodies were missing, including 70 bodies in the Timisoara Departmental Hospital morgue it said had disappeared after being loaded onto refrigerated trucks. The paper quoted Lorin Fortuna, president of the Timisoara council of the National Salvation Front, as saying he is convinced that many bodies were taken to Bucharest and cremated. Foreign Minister Sergiu Celac told visiting Helsinki Watch representatives he was disappointed that the U.S. government was so slow in responding to Romania's situation, said Gary Laber, executive director of the U.S.-based human rights organization, on Sunday. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze visited Saturday, and French Premier Roland Dumas and West German Foreign Minister Hans Dietrich Genscher are scheduled to visit this month. But despite considerable food and medical assistance from the United States, the highest-ranking U.S. official to visit so far has been Rep. Frank Wolf, R-Va..

DOC.HEAD: Six Children, Woman Killed In Alabama Foster Home Fire
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with seventh victim identified, smoke detectors required but reports conflicting on whether they were present, other detail. No pickup. Children's names, with two Kimberlys and two Jessies, boy named Marketta, are all cq as provided by state official.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MY2
DOC.TEXT: Fire swept through a private foster home in a rural area early Sunday, killing six young children placed there by state welfare authorities and a 66-year-old woman, officials said. Barbour County Coroner David Childs said the owners of the house, Robert and Lois Mitchell, escaped the 2 a.m. blaze uninjured, as did their three children and two other foster children. Alabama Fire Marshal John Robison said the cause of the fire that destroyed the large one-story house near the Bakerhill community was not immediately known. An investigation was continuing, he said. Childs said Mrs. Mitchell told him she thought the fire started in an area around the hot water heater, adding that the home was not being heated. The victims' bodies were badly burned and would be sent to a state forensics laboratory, he said. The fire was initially reported as a possible explosion, but Childs said there was none. He identified the children killed in the fire _ two girls and four boys _ as Kimberly Gilbert, 8; her brother Jessie, 10; Kimberly Walker, 5; and her brothers Larry, 10, Jessie, 7, and Marketta, 4. The seventh victim was Florene Burgess, 66. The Mitchells had taken her in ``just out of the goodness of their hearts,'' Childs said. The children who died in the fire had been assigned to the home, one of 4,000 private foster homes in the state, by the state Department of Human Resources, he said. All homes in the state, not just foster homes, are supposed to have smoke detectors, Robison said. He said initial reports from the scene indicated the Mitchell home may not have had detectors, but Mike Gibson, a spokesman for the state Department of Human Resources, said he understood there were detectors there. All private foster homes in the state are inspected before they are certified, he said. ``This is a case of folks who were just trying to help people,'' Childs said. ``There is no indication of foul play. She took all the children to church on Sunday and kept them in good shape and all.'' The surviving children, whose ages were not immediately known, were identified as Eric Mitchell, Michael Mitchell, Michelle Mitchell, Kevin Boyer and Brenda Gilbert.

DOC.HEAD: Former Nurse's Aide On Trail For Patient Death
DOC.TEXT: A slightly built former nurse's aide goes on trial Monday for first-degree murder in the death of one of seven elderly patients he's alternately confessed to and denied killing. Lawyers will begin Monday with jury selection for Jeffery Feltner's trial. If convicted, Feltner could go to the electric chair. Feltner, 27, stands 5 feet 3 inches tall and weighs barely 100 pounds. When he made anonymous phone calls to officials saying the seven patients did not die of natural causes but were strangled, some people didn't believe his tale. Although investigators were initially skeptical, authorities now say they believe Feltner asphyxiated the seven patients over an 18-month period to ease their suffering. The trial will look only at the death of Sara Abrams, 75, at New Life Acres nursing home in Melrose on Feb. 10, 1988. Feltner also faces a murder charge in Volusia County for the July 11, 1989, death of Doris Moriarty, 83, at Clyatt Memorial Center in Daytona Beach. Prosecutors say they are continuing their investigation of the remaining five deaths: four at New Life Acres from Feb. 7 to April 6, 1988; and one at Bowman's Nursing Center in Ormond Beach on July 27, 1989. A plea bargain fell apart late last Friday afternoon, when Circuit Judge E.L. Eastmoore refused to accept a deal that would have had Feltner plead guilty to second-degree murder in exchange for no more than 40 years in prison. ``He was willing to bite the bullet,'' said defense lawyer Howard Pearl, who said Feltner insists he didn't kill anyone. Feltner's mother, Shirley Hartman, said her son grew up a loner. She and his father split up three months before he was born, she said. She moved to Melrose in Putnam County in 1979, where Feltner graduated from Interlachen High School. In 1986, Hartman helped Feltner get a job at New Life Acres, where she worked as a nursing assistant. In June 1988, Feltner anonymously called a Gainesville television station and a mental health crisis center and told them he had killed five patients. But when questioned by detectives, Feltner denied it. He eventually pleaded guilty to making harassing phone calls, trespassing and making a false statement. He served a 127-day sentence and was freed Nov. 19, 1988. Feltner followed a similar pattern last summer. He told a Daytona Beach TV station, a mental health unit and his roommate about the most recent death. This time, when Daytona Beach detectives questioned him, Feltner told them about all seven killings, explaining that he did it to relieve the victims' suffering. But now he denies the killings. Both of the Daytona victims had been cremated, as were two of the four Melrose patients. Officials received permission from Abrams' daughter to exhume her remains, and prosecutors said an autopsy gave them the evidence they needed to back up Feltner's confessions. Abrams had broken ribs that showed she could have died when someone held her down while suffocating her, prosecutors said.

DOC.HEAD: Former Young Cult Member Tells of Drinking, Abuse
With AM-Cult Deaths
DOC.TEXT: A cult leader charged with murder in the slayings of five followers often beat children in the group and once planned an armed raid on a historic religious temple, said a young girl who lived among them. ``They would go to, like, rifle ranges and shoot. They had knives, too. I know they had machetes,'' said Bonnie Olivarez, ho was 11 when she lived with the group in the spring of 1988. ``It was kind of like normal at first and then it got really weird,'' said Bonnie, who was with her mother in the cult and now lives with her father in the Kansas City area. ``They were all religious and everything, but they didn't love me,'' she told The Kansas City Star in an interview published Sunday. The girl's mother, Deborah Sue Olivarez, is among 13 members of the cult charged with murder or conspiracy in the shootings of a five-member family whose bodies were found in a barn on the Kirtland, Ohio, farm where the group once lived. The group's leader, Jeffrey Lundgren, his wife and their 19-year-old son were arrested Sunday at a motel near San Diego. Eight other people, including Bonnie's mother, were arrested last week. Two of Lundgren's followers remained at large Sunday. The victims, found shot to death last week in a barn on the farm in Kirtland, are believed to be Dennis Avery, his wife, Cheryl, and their three young daughters. Authorities believe they died in April, shortly before the group left Ohio. Bonnie recalled that the group drank a lot and prepared for an assault on the Kirtland Historic Temple Site on May 3, 1988. The temple belongs to the Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints, which Lundgren and his followers quit to form their own group. In the days leading up to the planned assault, men in the cult donned camouflage clothing and took target practice, Bonnie said. On the morning of the planned attack, Lundgren went into the woods and came back saying God had told him to call off the operation, she said. Much of Bonnie's story was confirmed by Kirtland Police Chief Dennis Yarborough, who told the newspaper that he got an anonymous tip the group planned to seize the temple, which is based in Independence and shares some beliefs with the Mormon Church based in Salt Lake City. Lundgren kept a sizable and legal arsenal, Yarborough said. The weapons included bows and arrows, .22-caliber rifles and handguns, he said. Bonnie said the cult had about 20 rifles and handguns. At night and on weekends in 1988, the group donned military fatigues and army boots and watched violent films, held firing practice in the barn and practiced how to recognize types of weapons and load and unload them in the dark, investigators said. Bonnie said children in the cult were subject to ``sessions'' with Lundgren if they misbehaved, though she never had such a session. ``In a session he would yell at the top of his lungs,'' she said. ``He would hit you, and not with just his hands and stuff. He would use poles, too.''

DOC.HEAD: Witch Doctors, Sorcerers Flock To Oil-Rich Gulf Coast
DOC.TEXT: Self-proclaimed sorcerers and witch doctors have flocked to this Persian Gulf country, promising oil-rich natives that they can cure diseases and solve other problems for large fees, officials say. A police source said Sunday that an Indian sorceress who claimed the power of healing diseases was arrested. Two African witch doctors also were arrested in the United Arab Emirates recently after they claimed powers through their special relations with demons, the source said. ``The three cases discovered were but a few of a host of a new generation of witch doctors attracted by the money of the oil-rich Gulf,'' said the source, who could not be named under standing rules. The Indian, who was arrested Saturday, was identified as Faridah bin Amirjan. She claimed she could cure diseases and solve social problems merely by reading verses from the Moslem holy book, the Koran, for a reward to be decided by the patient. The two others were identified as Senegalese Mossa Mohammed Kawaji and Nigerian Dam Abu Bakr Mousa. Kawaji, who claimed to heal diseases and find stolen money, was arrested in Sharjah. He was quoted as telling police he knew ``all the 25 groups of demons,'' claiming they resembled black cats and lions. In one case, Kawaji was alleged to have charged a person seeking a cure $10,000 and 222 grams of gold. The Nigerian asked a person for $25,000, claiming he would pay him back with $250 million, the police source said. No money was returned, he said.

DOC.HEAD: 12 Illegal Immigrants Drown When Boat Capzizes
DOC.TEXT: A boat carrying 50 people hoping to enter the United States illegally capsized in heavy seas off the Dominican eastern coast. At least 12 people drowned, a newspaper reported Sunday. The daily Listin Diario said another 15 of those aboard were able to swim to shore in the Higuey province, about 140 miles east of Santo Domingo, the capital. Military planes searched Sunday for the 23 people still missing following the accident Wednesday night just three miles from shore, said a Dominican navy news release. The release also said another such boat believed to be carrying 25 Dominicans caught fire Friday in waters off San Pedro de Macoris. The navy said one body was recovered but no survivors were found. The accidents in Higuey and in San Pedro de Macoris, 45 miles east of Santo Domingo, were the first such reported this year. About 200,000 illegal immigrants try to sail from the Dominican Republic to Puerto Rico each year through the Mona Passage, a 100-mile wide-channel that separates the Dominican Republic from Puerto Rico. A navy report says 47 people drowned when their boats capsized last year, and 2,779 people were arrested by Dominican authorities. Thousands more are arrested and deported by U.S. Immigration and Naturalization officials.

DOC.HEAD: Garcia Says He'll Attend Summit If Bush Withdraws Troops From Panama
DOC.TEXT: President Alan Garcia said Sunday he will attend a drug summit in February with President Bush if the United States withdraws its troops from Panama by then. Following the U.S. intervention in Panama Dec. 20, Garcia cut off joint U.S.-Peruvian anti-drug patrols in his country and announced he would not attend the summit, saying he would not meet with the leader of an ``invading nation.'' On Dec. 26 Peru resumed the joint patrols. Government officials said last week that Peru would send a delegation to the summit with Bush and Presidents Virgilio Barco of Colombia and Jaime Paz Zamora of Bolivia, but Sunday's announcement was the first signal that Garcia may change his mind about attending. The summit is scheduled for Feb. 15 in Cartagena, Colombia. ``If the American troops are withdrawn from Panamanian territory, President Garcia will go to the summit,'' said presidential minister Rodolfo Beltran. Garcia later confirmed the possibility in brief statements to reporters. Peru is the world's principal producer of coca leaf, the raw material for cocaine. The Bush Administration has proposed spending $2.2 billion over the next five years in the three Andean nations to stop the drug trade. U.S. troops invaded Panama to oust Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega and bring him back to the United States to stand trial on drug trafficking charges. A civilian government led by Guillermo Endara, who won elections in May that Noriega annuled, has taken power in the Central American nation. About 14,000 troops joined the 12,000 American soldiers already stationed in Panama for the U.S. action, and Washington has given no deadline for their withdrawal.

DOC.HEAD: Rain Drenches Southeast, Sunny Skies Elsewhere
DOC.TEXT: Rain drenched parts of the Southeast and West on Sunday, with sunny skies elsewhere and snow in the mountains of Nevada, Idaho and Wyoming. Rain stretched from the Carolinas to portions of Tennessee, Georgia, Florida, Alabama, Mississippi and much of Louisiana. Montana, Idaho, Wyoming and the northern Pacific Coast also received rain, which turned to snow in the higher elevations of Nevada, Idaho and Wyoming. Albany, Ga., got nearly 2.2 inches of rain in the six hours ending at 7 a.m. EST, the National Weather Service said. About 50 homes in nearby Sylvester, Ga., were evacuated because of flooding, the weather service said. Crescent City, Calif., received nearly 2.5 inches of rain in the same six-hour period. From 3 to 5 inches of snow fell overnight near Lake Tahoe. Wind gusted up to 87 mph in Livingston, Mont., and up to 60 mph in Cody, Wyo. Marquette, Mich., had a record high temperature of 42 degrees, breaking the date's previous mark of 37 degrees set in 1965. Mason City, Iowa, also set a new high _ 47 degrees. The previous record was 44 degrees set in 1963. The cold spot in the nation's Lower 48 states was -7 degrees in Caribou and Houlton, Maine. DOC.HEAD: Gov't Announces Price Increases on Milk, Meat, Bread
DOC.TEXT: The government on Sunday tripled water and sewer rates and raised prices more than 25 percent on milk, meat and bread as part of efforts to move Hungary's economy toward capitalism. It is the third Eastern European country in a week to announce broad economic changes to curtail more than 40 years of price controls and subsidies implemented by Communist leadership. Most of the price increases were to take effect Monday, with some coming into effect Feb. 1, the state news agency MTI reported. The government announcement, carried by MTI, said meat prices will rise by 32 percent, bread by 26 percent and milk and dairy products at least 42 percent. The cost of cigarettes, beer and spirits is to rise by 20-22 percent, while rents will rise by 35 percent as subsidies are withdrawn, MTI said. Water and sewage rates will increase 336 percent because of a cut in state subsidies and previously ``irrationally low'' prices, MTI said. To offset the increases, the government will raise state pensions and family allowances, the news agency said. Hungarians would have to pay at least 45 percent more for urban public transport and 55 percent more in the Budapest area, the news agency said. The price increases will result partly from the state removing controls on prices as part of an austerity budget adopted by Parliament last month. On Jan. 1, Poland and Yugoslavia announced broad changes intended to transform those economies to capitalism, cut inflation and make their currencies convertible for international trade.

DOC.HEAD: Priest Ousted Over Dress Code Supported by Parishioners
DOC.TEXT: A Roman Catholic priest who was fired for denying Holy Communion to worshipers dressed in mini-skirts and shorts got support Sunday from a parishioner who said the priest was only trying to set a standard. The Rev. Roger Griese, 73, was placed on retirement from Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church last week by Archbishop Daniel Pilarczyk, who objected to Griese's refusal of communion to those worshipers wearing clothing Griese deemed inappropriate for church. ``What did Father Griese do that deserves his dismissal?'' Debra O'Laughlin said in a letter she read in the basement after Sunday's Mass. ``He set a standard, tried to tell people the proper dress and behavior in the proper place, and got fired,'' her letter said. Ms. O'Laughlin had asked Griese's successor if she could read the letter during the service, but the Rev. Francis Pilliod told her she would have to read it in the basement afterward. Pilliod's decision was met with shouts of disapproval from the congregation. Also Sunday, parishioner Joseph Cleary said he sent Pilarczyk a letter signed by about 100 people in support of Griese, who plans to appeal his forced retirement to the Vatican. Cleary said the signatures accounted for virtually all members of the parish. ``It seemed to us that he (Pilarczyk) didn't have any idea that the parish stood behind father 100 percent,'' Cleary said. ``Father isn't doing this all on his own. It's the rest of the parishioners who feel that way.'' A letter from Pilarczyk was read during Saturday's Mass explaining his decision to oust Griese. ``It is not intended as a penalty, but reflects a judgment on my part that Father Griese is no longer able to fulfill the office of pastor,'' wrote Pilarczyk, head of the Cincinnati archdiocese. ``This decision has not been pleasant or easy. I ask that all of us pray for Father Griese.'' Griese, who headed Sacred Heart for 21 years, had twice denied communion to a man who came to church wearing shorts. He also criticized the man before the congregation. Griese remains a priest in good standing and is entitled to retirement benefits.

DOC.HEAD: Five Die When Hot Water Heater's Flame Goes Out
DOC.TEXT: Natural gas seeped from a malfunctioning hot water heater through a home near this southwestern town Sunday, killing a woman and her four children, firefighters said. The water heater's flame apparently went out while Fatma Sila, 29, was taking a bath, the fire department reported. She was found asphyxiated in the bathtub, while her children, aged 3, 4, 6, and 7, died in an adjacent room. Their father, Bouchta Sila, a farm worker, was at work at the time. His nationality and that of the children was not known. Ms. Sila was a Moroccan. Manosque is in the rugged Provence hills, 55 miles north of Marseille.

DOC.HEAD: Two Palestinians Die, Nine Activists Banned From Traveling
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 15 grafs to UPDATE with identity of other Palestinians banned, Tel Aviv mayor says he wants to talk peace with Arafat. Pick up 12th pvs, `In the...'
DOC.TEXT: Two 18-year-old Palestinians died Sunday of gunshot wounds after clashes with soldiers, and Israeli authorities banned nine pro-PLO activists from traveling abroad. Palestinian leaders charged Sunday that the three-month travel bans on the nine pro-PLO activists imposed by Interior Minister Aryeh Deri were an attempt to disrupt U.S.-backed efforts to arrange a Palestinian-Israeli meeting in Cairo. Those targeted included Sari Nusseibeh and Faisal Husseini, the two most prominent Palestinians involved in behind-the-scenes diplomatic efforts. Husseini complained that Israeli authorities were trying to nominate their own Palestinian representatives for the proposed talks and block any role for the Palestine Liberation Organization. Also ordered to stay in the country were Nablus businessman Saeed Kanaan, activist Zuahira Kamal and a delegation of five Palestinian trade union leaders who were to attend a conference in Egypt, Palestinian sources said. Nusseibeh was reportedly turned back at the Allenby Bridge while en route to Jordan and others had planned trips to Egypt, which has been consulting Palestinians about a list of 10 negotiators to meet with Israel. The English-language Jerusalem Post and Hebrew Maariv dailies said the travel bans appeared aimed at disrupting contacts between local Palestinian leaders and Yasser Arafat's PLO. Israel considers the PLO a terrorist group and refuses to negotiate with it. Also Sunday, Tel Aviv's mayor said he was prepared to meet with Arafat and criticized Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's position toward the organization. The Interior Ministry issued a statement saying Deri banned the Palestinians from leaving because ``he was convinced there was a serious suspicion that their exit abroad could harm state security, because they could have met with hostile elements.'' An Israeli official who briefed a reporter Sunday said he did not know if the travel ban was related to the diplomatic efforts but added the three-month restriction was likely to expire before any Israeli-Palestinian meeting was arranged in Cairo. The official said ``Israel is not fully satisfied'' with Washington's response to Israel's demands for U.S. guarantees that the PLO will be excluded from the negotiating. Israeli sources confirmed media reports that U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III sent a letter to Israel refusing to give a rigid guarantee and backing Arab demands that issues other than Israel's peace initiative could be raised at the Cairo meeting. The sources said unless Israel could get stronger American guarantees, a Washington meeting that was planned to help set up the Cairo talks might not be convened. Baker had planned to invite Israel's and Egypt's foreign ministers to the Washington session later this month. In Tel Aviv, Mayor Shlomo Lahat said Israel will have negotiate with the PLO and said he is ``ready to talk to Arafat, if it is permitted by law,'' said city spokesman Benny Cohen. Lahat, of Shamir's Likud bloc, criticized Shamir, who has ruled out any contacts with the PLO. Meetin with PLO members without government authoritization carries a maximum three-year prison sentence. In the West Bank town of Bethlehem, about 2,000 people attended a funeral for Fadi Zabakli. Zabakli died earlier Sunday of gunshot wounds suffered in Bethlehem on Dec. 28. The army said the teen-ager was wearing a mask and fled from soldiers who ordered him to stop for questioning. Several hundred soldiers in Bethlehem's Manger Square watched without intervening as activists marching in the funeral procession waved outlawed Palestinian flags and broke into rhythmic chants of ``With our soul and our blood we will revenge you, Fadi!'' Church bells pealed a mourning cadence, and shopkeepers throughout Bethlehem staged a spontaneous protest strike. The second death came in the West Bank village of Attil. Residents there told Arab reporters that Kamal Abu Khalil, 18, was fatally wounded in the head Sunday when soldiers raiding the village opened fire on Palestinians erecting barricades and throwing stones. Israel radio quoted a military source as saying soldiers raided Attil shortly after masked youths torched an Israeli bus carrying Arab workers to jobs in Israel. The radio said Khalil was among a group of masked assailants. The army has orders to arrest Palestinians wearing masks. The deaths brought to 644 the number of Palestinians killed by Israelis during the two-year uprising against Israeli rule in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. At least 166 Palestinians also have been slain by fellow Arabs, and 43 Israelis have been killed. On the Jordanian border, Israeli troops killed an infiltrator dressed in a Jordanian army uniform, the fifth shooting incident this year along the Jordan border, an army spokesman said.

DOC.HEAD: Another Woman Linked to Stuart Probe
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after 7th, `Stuart, who ...' to CLARIFY no arrests have been made; ADDS two grafs at bottom to UPDATE with brother under surveillance, report of another man in car during drop.
DOC.TEXT: Charles Stuart bought a $250 brooch last week and was repeatedly called by a woman while he was hospitalized, leading investigators to suspect a romantic motive for him to kill his pregnant wife, wound himself and blame the attack on a mugger, published reports said Sunday. Stuart, who received a nationwide outpouring of sympathy after his cries for help over his car phone led police to his dying wife Oct. 23, jumped to his death from a Boston Harbor bridge Thursday after becoming a suspect in her slaying. Authorities said he committed suicide after his brother, Matthew, told investigators Stuart murdered his wife. Carol Stuart was shot after the couple left a birthing class. Her son, delivered by Caesarean section, died 17 days later. Authorities sought genetic tests to determine if the child was fathered by Stuart, and they continued to look for insurance policies for a motive. The search for the gun used in the shootings went into a fourth day Sunday with no results. Matthew Stuart, 23, said his brother passed him the gun and his wife's purse the night of the shootings and that he later threw them into a river in Revere, a Boston suburb. The bag has been recovered. Stuart, who was shot in the stomach, provided a description of an assailant, and the crime riveted the nation as a chilling example of urban violence. The drama was bolstered by transcripts of Stuart's gripping call for help on his phone. No arrests have been made in the case. Police have questioned a woman who worked with Stuart at Edward F. Kakas & Sons, a fur shop where Charles was manager, the Boston Globe reported Sunday. In a search of Stuart's Reading home, police found telephone bills that indicate she had been using his credit card to call him at the hospital, said Reading police Detective Dave Saunders. The woman was a Brown University graduate now in graduate school and worked at Kakas for the last two summers, the Globe said, quoting neighbors and friends. Police would not release the woman's identity. Police also are investigating Stuart's actions on Tuesday, when he bought a new car and a $250 14-carat gold brooch at Marco Jewelers in Peabody, the Globe said. Police are trying to determine if the jewelry was a present for the woman, the newspaper said. John White, the jewelry store manager, said he was surprised by Stuart's demeanor while making the purchase. ``He didn't express any grief. None at all. That struck everyone as funny,'' White said. In October, the woman was questioned by police and had said she and her boyfriend had socialized with Stuart and his wife. The district attorney's office has sent blood samples to a lab for DNA testing to establish the parentage of the child. Results will take at least three weeks, said Dr. Gerald Fegin of the state Medical Examiner's office. Police said they are also looking for insurance policies. Stuart has collected $82,000 on an insurance policy from his wife's position as a lawyer. A search of the couple's home turned up another $100,000 policy on her, authorities said. John Julian, a spokesman for the district attorney's office, said Sunday that Matthew Stuart is under surveillance. The Boston Herald said another man was in the car with Matthew when Stuart tossed him the bag. The man has denied any involvement.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Troupe Presents `The Hope,' Soviet Russia's First Rock Opera
DOC.TEXT: Russia's first rock opera, set in 1806 with an elaborate avant-garde staging, cast of 60 and a message ``to bridge the distance between us with love,'' has opened for four weeks at the City Center. ``Junon and Avos _ the Hope'' is interesting. Though it will occasionally remind New Yorkers of theater from ``South Pacific'' to ``Jesus Christ Superstar,'' ``Hair'' and ``Les Miserables,'' it isn't really a copycat show. The music is fat-chorded guitar rock underlined with synthesizers, loud but not superloud. However, it isn't all rock. There's a choir at the back of the stage which sometimes sings church music. Four deep-voiced naval officers sing what could be a lovely sad Russian lullaby. Some of the male solos lean toward Yves Montand's style. One of the forging-ahead songs, sung with serious intensity by the men, has the catchy, fun beat of ``Honey Bun'' from ``South Pacific.'' The story, said to be true, is easy to follow. It's written in the program and Broadway veteran Philip Casnoff explains it from time to time. ``The Hope'' was first performed in Moscow's Lenin Komsomol Theater in 1982. Pierre Cardin took that production to his Paris theater in 1983 and is the producer of these timely performances. The stage is a series of plastic panels, lighted from underneath, with some give when stepped on. They're steeply raked. They don't meet in the center, leaving a long, narrow walkway for center-stage entrances and exits. At the beginning, a ship is poised center stage. It is hoisted up, still in sight. Count Rezanov wants to take two ships, Junon and Avos, to San Francisco and open trade and relations between the two countries. He sails. Spain tells the governor that trade can only be with Spain. Rezanov seduces the governor's daughter Conchita. He returns to Russia to get permission to marry her, outside his church, but dies. She waits 35 years, learns he is dead and becomes California's first nun. Finally, the entire cast, some changed into jeans, gather to sing ``Alleluia,'' with lyrics imploring peace. It starts like an oratorio. Then the rock group kicks in and, with the younger players looking happier, they join arms, sway their bodies in circles and sing it like the tribe from ``Hair.'' Nikolai Karachentsev was a strong, rugged-faced Count Rezanov, a Romeo with a hand mike. In America, he'd probably become a TV private eye or the next Mick Jagger. In Russia, he acts in contemporary plays and classics and makes movies. Yelena Shanina was a delicate Conchita, her small head and blonde hair making her look like a Russian ballerina. Program notes say that Alexander Abdulov, the narrator, is popular in the Komsomol's musicals, in TV and movies. Alexis Ribinkov, who wrote the music, studied with Aram Khachaturian. He composes classical music, scores films and has written a second contemporary opera. Poet Andrey Voznesensky wrote the lyrics and book, based on one of his poems. Director Mark Zakharov is artistic director of Lenin Komsomol Theater. Lucy Jarvis, the American producer, took ``Duke Ellington's Sophisticated Ladies'' to the Soviet Union. Bolshoi Ballet star Vladimir Vassiliev choreographed the show. His new pas de deux, ``Elegy,'' will be performed on American Ballet Theater's 1990 tour, which could be looked on as fulfilling part of Count Rezanov's dream.

DOC.HEAD: Lima Suffering From Severe Water Shortage
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of residents lined up Sunday to get water from trucks and scores of people filled jugs and bottles from downtown fountains as Lima suffered through a severe water shortage. Lower than normal rainfall in the Andes Mountains has caused the shortage, and a summer heat wave and electricity rationing caused by terrorist attacks on power lines are aggravating the problem. The minister of energy and mines, Mario Samame, said the situation is so bad that if the city doesn't take urgent measures to conserve water, water services could collapse. In an interview published Sunday in the Lima newspaper Expreso, Walter Gomez of the state weather service said the city of 7 million is tapping water reserves in nearby lakes that it will need in the dry months of June to November. He said the Rimac River, Lima's principal source of water which flows down from the high Andes to the east, is running at less than half its normal level for this time of year.

DOC.HEAD: Inmates Injured in 20-Minute Rampage
DOC.TEXT: A detention center remained locked down Sunday following a brief uprising among inmates that left 27 of them injured, authorities said. Black and Hispanic inmates at the San Diego County South Bay Detention Center began fighting Saturday night, the sheriff's department said. No guards or sheriff's deputies were hurt as they quelled the 20-minute outbreak. Sheriff's Deputy Jim Cook said inmates ``tore mirrors off of the wall; light fixtures were torn down; some of the bunks were disassembled and the parts were used as weapons.'' The cause of the disturbance remained under investigation. The cell block was designed for 24 inmates but held 113, authorities said. Cook said inmates used ``a lot of whatever they could get their hands on to create makeshift weapons, that's what was used. Some of the inmates were stabbed by crudely made stabbing weapons.'' None of the inmates was seriously injured, although 18 were taken to hospitals for treatment.

DOC.HEAD: Scottish Actor Ian Charleson Dies After Fight With AIDS
DOC.NOTE: EDS: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with reax from Ian McKellen, trims. Pick up 9th pvs, `Charleson, the...'
DOC.TEXT: Actor Ian Charleson, who starred in the film ``Chariots of Fire'' as an Olympic runner whose religious faith took precedence over his desire to compete, has died of complicatons from AIDS, his agent said Sunday. He was 40. The Scottish actor, who recently played ``Hamlet'' at London's National Theater, died at his home in London on Saturday evening ``following a courageous struggle with the AIDS virus,'' Michael Whitehall said. He said the cause of death was septicemia, a disease caused by microorganisms in the blood. Charleson, who received critical praise for a series of stage roles, achieved international fame in the 1981 film ``Chariots of Fire'' in which he played Eric Liddell, a Scottish missionary and runner who refused to compete on a Sunday. The film won the Academy Award for best picture. He also appeared in the 1982 Oscar-winning film ``Gandhi'' as Charlie Andrews, the priest who was a friend of Indian independence leader Mohandas K. Gandhi. ``He was the most unmannered and unactorish of actors: always truthful, always honest,'' fellow actor Ian McKellen said Sunday night. Charleson also was a beautiful singer who ``had the most pure tenor I've ever heard,'' McKellen said in an interview. Mark Fisher, an opposition Labor Party spokesman on the arts, said Charleson's widely acclaimed performance as Hamlet ``indicated that an enormous career lay ahead of him. This is a terrible tragedy for the British theater.'' His last performance came just nine weeks ago. ``After nearly four hours on stage he was given a standing ovation,'' Whitehall said. ``It was clear that he was exhausted but his courage, not only in being on that stage but giving us the performance of his life, left our applause and cheers seeming very inadequate.'' Charleson, the son of a printer, was born in Edinburgh Aug. 11, 1949. He won a scholarship to the capital's Royal High School and went on to study architecture at Edinburgh University. His interest in acting developed, Charleson once said, when he discovered he had the ability ``to make people laugh and make them cry.'' He studied at the London Academy of Music and Dramatic Art and began his stage career in London at the Young Vic Theater from 1972 to 1974. His performances with the National Theater included roles in ``Julius Caesar'' and ``Volpone''in 1977, and ``Guys and Dolls'' in 1984. He received particular acclaim for his performances in two American plays at the National _ Sam Shepard's ``Fool for Love'' in 1985, and a 1988 production of Tennessee Williams' ``Cat on a Hot Tin Roof,'' in which he played Brick. One of his recent television roles was the lead in ``Troubles'' a film version of J.G. Farrell's book about Ireland's fight for independence. There will be a private family funeral in Scotland later this week and a memorial service in London later in the year, Whitehall said. Acquired immune deficiency syndrome is caused by a virus that damages the body's immune system, leaving victims susceptible to infections and cancer. It is spread most often through sexual contact, needles or syringes shared by drug abusers, infected blood or blood products, and from pregnant women to their offspring. The scientific name for the virus is human immunodeficiency virus, or HIV.

DOC.HEAD: Shuttle Countdown Continues, But Weather Looks Bad For Monday Launch
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 3rd, ``There is...' to UPDATE with fueling of shuttle. Edits 4th graf to conform and picks up 5th graf pvs, `The intricate...'
DOC.TEXT: NASA officials decided Sunday to continue the countdown toward a Monday launch of space shuttle Columbia, although forecasters gave only 1-in-5 odds that the weather will permit it. ``There is a chance and we'd like to be ready to take that chance,'' said William B. Lenoir, the head of NASA's space flight program. As long there was more than a zero possibility for liftoff on Monday, he said, the shuttle's huge fuel tanks would be filled beginning late Sunday. ``There is a 20 percent chance we will get off,'' Lenoir told reporters. ``We've all been here often enough to know that what is predicted does not always happen, and sometimes good things happen when bad is predicted.'' Kennedy Space Center spokesman Carl Kristoferson said fueling of the shuttle began at 10:53 p.m. EST. The space center has been socked in by fog for several days at 8:10 a.m. EST, the earliest the shuttle can be launched Monday. The launch opportunity lasts until 9:02. The intricate timing on this 33rd shuttle flight is dictated by Columbia's main mission, to retrieve a science laboratory the size of a small bus that has been in orbit around Earth since its launch in April 1984 from the shuttle Challenger. Columbia must be launched into the same path as the satellite, which is called LDEF, for Long Duration Exposure Facility. The aerial chase will have the shuttle trailing the LDEF in the same plane, or driving lane. By flying in a lower orbit and thereby taking less time to go around the Earth, the shuttle eventually will catch up to the satellite, snag it with its 50-foot crane, and bring it into the cargo bay. Mission specialist Bonnie Dunbar is set to be at the space shuttle controls during the retrieval. If the shuttle takes off Monday, the retrieval would take place on Thursday, Saturday or Sunday, depending on the exact minute of launch. The LDEF is a 12-sided frame on which are mounted 57 trays of experiments including ones with tomato seeds and different metals and a a mechanism to catch interplanetary dust. Experimenters hope to gain valuable information about the universe and its origins from postflight examinations of cosmic dust, interstellar gases and previously unobtainable subatomic radiation particles. Students from the fifth grade through college will try to see which of 12{ million tomato seeds will grow. Engineers will learn how materials, coatings, electronic parts and thermal control systems are affected by long exposure to space. Commander Dan Brandenstein and his crew of four also will launch the fift of a series of Navy communications satellites and conduct eight scientific experiments. Others on the mission are pilot Jim Wetherbee and mission specialists Marsha Ivins and David Low. The flight is to last 10 days, matching the previous shuttle record, to test equipment for longer shuttle missions. Flights of 16 and 28 days also are planned as NASA prepares to the day when astronauts will be aboard a space station for up to six months.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
President Says Military Men Killed Priests
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to reorganize, ADD background. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Military men committed the Nov. 16 massacre of six Jesuit priests, their housekeeper and her daughter, President Alfredo Cristiani said Sunday night. ``It has been determined that there was involvement of some elements of the armed forces,'' Cristiani said in a five-minute nationally broadcast address. He termed the massacre ``abominable.'' The president did not specify who was implicated in the crime, nor did he indicate the rank or number of those responsible. Earlier, Col. Rene Emilio Ponce, head of El Salvador's joint chiefs of staff, told The Associated Press that members of an elite battalion have been confined to their base and were being questioned in connection with the slayings. However, he emphasized that the 47 members of the elite Atlacatl battalion _ including two officers _ are not under arrest. It was unclear whether those soldiers and officers were the ones to whom Cristiani referred. Priests and educators Ignacio Ellacuria, Ignacio Martin-Baro, Segundo Montes, Amado Lopez, Juan Ramon Moreno and Joaquin Lopez Lopez were taken from their beds in their on-campus residence before dawn Nov. 16 and killed. The priests' housekeeper, Julia Ramos, and her 15-year-old daughter Celina, were also slain. Ellacuria was the rector of the UCA, and Martin-Baro was its vice rector. Ponce said in a telephone interview that the men being interrogated were members of the unit that conducted a search of the Jesuits' residence at the order's Central American University, or UCA, two days before the priests were slain. Asked if the men were implicated by evidence other than the fact that they conducted the search, Ponce said he could not comment. A UCA employee has said she saw men in military uniforms outside the residence shortly before the shots that killed the priests were heard. The woman, Lucia Barrera, has been taken for her own safety to the United States, where she is under the protection of the Jesuits. Cristiani said in his speech Sunday that the work of a commission investigating the slayings ``has been from the start professional and exhaustive.'' Agents from the United States, Spain and Scotland Yard have aided in the probe. The president also said a ``Special Commission of Honor,'' including high-ranking military men and respected civilian lawyers, has been created ``to determine the exact circumstances (of the slayings) and clarify the truth in its complete magnitude.'' He said the new commission would work with investigators ``to deduce responsibilities and make sure justice is done.'' He said punishment would be meted out ``down to the last person implicated.'' Cristiani asked Salvadorans to avoid speculation while the commissions carry out their work. The priests were slain five days after leftist rebels of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front, or FMLN, launched their biggest offensive of their 10-year-old revolution. The guerrillas have battled a succession of U.S.-backed governments, which they allege serve as civilian facades for repressive military rule. The far right, which is blamed for the death-squad murders of several thousand suspected leftists in the early 1980s, had consistently denounced the left-leaning UCA Jesuits as subversive ideologues. In 1980, El Salvador's Roman Catholic Archbishop Oscar Romero was murdered, and right-wing death squads were widely believed to be responsible. The assassins were never brought to justice. Cristiani has vowed his administration would find and punish those responsible for the murder of the Jesuit priests. He offered a $250,000 reward for information leading to the murderers' arrest and conviction. In the days following the slayings, several high-ranking military officers, including Col. Francisco Elena Fuentes, 1st army brigade commander, publicly accused the rebels of the murders.

DOC.HEAD: FDA Ban on Bogus Baldness `Remedies' May Boost Rogaine Sales
DOC.TEXT: The federal government's ban on non-prescription anti-baldness drugs, which goes into effect Monday, is expected to boost the already increasing sales of Rogaine, the only scientifically proven hair-loss treatment. The Food and Drug Administration said in July there is no evidence to support the hair-growth or anti-baldness claims of hundreds of over-the-counter creams, lotions, vitamins and food supplements. American men spend as much as $300 a year on these so-called baldness remedies. The agency said that beginning Monday it will remove such products from the market on a case-by-case basis if their distributors continue to make such claims. The publicity from the ban as well as more effective advertising by Upjohn Co. of Kalamazoo have contributed to an increase in the sales of Upjohn's Rogaine, a prescription baldness drug that received FDA approval in 1988 but has been slow to catch on, analysts say. Rogaine sales in the fourth quarter of 1989 totaled about $21 million, compared with a disappointing $5 million in the fourth quarter of 1988, when it first was introduced in the United States, said Ronald Nordmann, an analyst who follows Rogaine for PaineWebber Inc. in New York. He attributed the increase to more forceful advertising. Total U.S. sales of Rogaine in 1989 were about $65 million, Nordmann said. But he said the drug is still unprofitable because about $50 million was spent on advertising. He estimated 1990 sales would jump to about $100 million, and even higher if the FDA approves Upjohn's similar product for female pattern baldness this year. Upjohn applauded the FDA's ban on its would-be competitors, but spokeswoman Kaye Bennett said Friday it would be difficult to isolate the ban's effect on Rogaine's improving sales. ``Sales have certainly been influenced by the introduction of the 1-800 number'' in Rogaine ads, Bennett said. Since it was introduced in ads in May, the toll-free number has generated about 200,000 calls from people wanting more information about the product, Bennett said. Upjohn also has offered financial incentives of $10 to consumers who see their dermotologists regarding hair loss _ regardless of whether Rogaine is prescribed _ and $5 in coupons for each of the first four months of Rogaine treatment. The patented drug is a 2 percent solution of the drug minoxidil, which originally was developed to treat high blood pressure but was found to have the unintended side effect of promoting hair growth. The solution, which is applied externally to the scalp, costs about $60 for a one-month supply. Once the treatments are stopped, any new hair will probably fall out, company officials say. The drug has been shown in testing to grow hair in about 39 percent of young men who are in the early stages of balding. William Gilbertson, director of the FDA's over-the-counter drug review program, said he expects many of the non-prescription products now on the market to simply change their labels to promise ``fuller, thicker-looking hair'' rather than hair growth to conform with the new regulations. Many of these products are sold by mail, in drug stores and through barbers and beauticians. One well-known product, the Helsinki Formula, is in compliance with the FDA regulations because it does not promise hair growth but suggests that a cleansing agent it contains ``can relieve the impediment to hair growing naturally,'' said Hal Z. Lederman, president of Pantron I of Los Angeles, the product's maker. Nordmann, the industry analyst, said he doubts Upjohn will pick up a substantial amount of consumers who typically buy such products because of Rogaine's higher price and the long-term commitment involved in its use. ``But even if a portion of a $300 million-a-year market swings over to Rogaine, that's potential for a significant increase,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Texas Company Models American Videotex on French System
DOC.TEXT: Videotex, the delivery of information and services on a computer screen, has struggled to gain a foothold in U.S. homes, but a Texas company figures that what works on Rue d'Orme in France will play on Elm Street, U.S.A. U.S. Videotel Inc., based in Houston and financed by a Swiss backer, is patterned after the French government-owned Minitel system. Minitel is an in-home computer linkup to services ranging from information, like sports scores and theater schedules, to shopping, games and banking services. Videotel even uses terminals made by the same company that makes Minitel's computers, and one service allows connection to the French system. Minitel is the result of a total revamping of the French communications system, including a $1 billion investment over five years. In France, the terminals are provided free, but users are charged to connect to the system. Past American videotex efforts have failed. Several companies have poured millions into development only to be met with resistance by computer-phobic consumers. Videotel believes it has two hooks to land the domestic market: local information, including restaurant menus and movie schedules, and its own computer terminal, eliminating the need for the user to own a personal computer. Those two factors distinguish Videotel from the main U.S. consumer-oriented videotex service, Prodigy, a joint venture of Sears, Roebuck and Co. and International Business Machines Corp. Prodigy requires a PC plus a modem for customers to communicate with the service via a telephone line. The same factors helped persuade J.C. Penney Co. Inc. to sign on with Videotel last week to make its catalog products available to subscribers beginning Feb. 1, said Art Steinberg, Penney's catalog business development manager. Also, Videotel has had enough success in Houston that Penney's can see how a market responds, Steinberg said. Penney's, which also participates in Prodigy, may use Videotel to advertise its store merchandise, he said. For $14.95 a month, Videotel subscribers get a ``dumb'' computer terminal that provides access to a menu of services. Customers with PCs and modems can get the programming for $9.95 a month, the same price as Prodigy. The U.S. company takes ``the best parts of the French system, and combines that with our strategies that have been molded to the American structure,'' said Craig Spencer, head of Videotel's Dallas operation. Since debuting in April, Videotel has signed up 23,000 subscribers in Houston, and added 2,350 in Dallas-Fort Worth since becoming available there the first of November. Videotel was founded three years ago and is bankrolled by an anonymous Swiss investor, Spencer said. The company started out in Texas because it first reached a marketing agreement with Southwestern Bell Telephone Co. for Houston. The company will expand next into Canada, where it also has agreements with the telephone company, Spencer said. Videotel has a goal of about 4.5 million homes within five years. Despite Videotel's early success, skeptics remain. Efrem Sigel, president of Communications Trends Inc. in Larchmont, N.Y., disputes the perception that videotex has been successful in France, where he said the public has been ``force fed'' Minitel because of its government ownership. Videotex is even less likely to succeed as a mass medium in the United States, the analyst said. ``Nowhere have I seen it demonstrated that (videotex) is a cost-efficient way to deliver information into homes,'' he said. Whereas business success may depend on immediate information, ``consumers don't need information instantaneously,'' he said. ``What is it that the consumer is going to use this for that he can't get on television or in newspapers?'' he asked. Sigel relegates Videotel to ``a new generation of companies that will lose tens of millions of dollars on this stuff.'' A survey by the Videotex Industry Association said only 28 percent of U.S. households have PCs, and only 6 percent have the necessary modems. Videotel figures that by providing its own terminal, it can overcome those limitations. ``The network is basically a mall,'' Spencer said. Users can shop from ``GateWay Square,'' which includes several vendors, or they can play games, call up news stories, look up information in an on-line encyclopedia, check menus and prices at area restaurants and find out what's playing when at local movie houses. Some banks also allow customers access to their accounts through Videotel. Negotiations are under way with vendors to allow customers to order tickets to events from, or even to order a takeout meal at their favorite restaurant. ``We want this to be a utility,'' Spencer said, as indispensable as electricity, running water and the telephone. The system is analogous to cable television in that many of the services are included in the basic rate while others, such as bill-paying or tying into France's Minitel, cost extra. But even Spencer concedes that Videotel's success will depend on the quality of information and services it provides, and that the future is far from assured. ``The market is so virgin to this type of technology,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Coupon-Clipper Goes to Trial on Fraud, Conspiracy Charges
LaserPhoto MH1
DOC.TEXT: A woman who hoarded thousands of coupons and raked through the trash to get proofs of purchase for refund deals faces trial Monday on federal charges of mail fraud and conspiracy to distribute fake coupons. Connie Arvidson, a 34-year-old wife, mother and self-described ``Dumpster lady,'' said she became obsessed over the years in her quest for special offers through rebates and coupons. But she said she didn't know the coupons she bought through an advertisement in a coupon magazine were counterfeit. At times, she would pay garbage collectors to retrieve products that qualified for special offers. At one point, 1,000 liquor bottles a week soaked in her bathtub to facilitate label-removing and hundreds of thousands of coupons were jammed into files. But it's the coupons, not the refund programs, that have brought her to the eve of a trial. Assistant U.S. Attorney Steve Sucsy, who will prosecute the case in Dallas, where the case originates, would not comment the case Friday, with the trial so close. But in the past, he has said: ``There is no way she didn't know what she was doing.'' Mrs. Arvidson and nine others were indicted in June 1989 in connection with a $2 million counterfeit coupon scam. According to the indictment, the coupons for food and other products were printed and distributed nationwide from Texas. Mrs. Arvidson is accused of knowingly buying and distributing fake coupons. ``It's like a nightmare that I have to sit in a courtroom with some of these people I don't even know and see them try to hurt me for something I never did,'' Mrs. Arvidson said. ``I've just got to think I'm going to come home and be with my little girl.'' The trial of Mrs. Arvidson, along with two San Antonio men named in the indictment, is expected to last a week. The charges against David Rees and James Floyd Richards of conspiracy to commit mail fraud relate to the printing and distribution of the coupons, Sucsy said. The seven others, the man accused of advertising the coupons and six accused of purchasing them from him through the mail, have made plea bargains, Sucsy said Friday. Mrs. Arvidson said she and other refunders had joked that the coupons might be stolen. But she believed the ad was legitimate since it was in magazines. ``If I'm guilty of anything, then maybe I'm guilty of accepting stolen goods,'' she said. And by stolen, she says, she thought the coupons might have been taken from Dumpsters. She plans to bring to court as evidence of Dumpster ``treasures'' three large rolls, each containing 10,000 bar code strips for light bulbs. Mrs. Arvidson said got the bar code strips, which could be used as proofs of purchase, by trading with a woman who plucked them from a Dumpster behind the light bulb factory. In return, the woman got material qualifying the sender for rebates from a diaper manufacturer. ``In refunding, I quit being surprised,'' Mrs. Arvidson said. ``I found anything could happen in refunding.'' She said her ``little job'' brought her satisfaction and she became known in the world of refunding. Mrs. Arvidson estimates she made $200 a week at her rebating peak. On top of that, she paid little for groceries because of coupons. ``I got known as the `diaper, Exxon, Seagram Cooler lady,''' Mrs. Arvidson said about the proofs of purchase that she accumulated and then rebated, traded or sold to other refunders. ``Everybody loves you if you have something,'' she said. ``Nobody wants to know you if you have nothing. That's what it's like in refunding.'' Mrs. Arvidson said she has little left: Her husband has gotten disability payments after a car wreck but is no longer employed and she's filed for bankruptcy. Mrs. Arvidson said that although others accused in the coupon scam have made plea bargains, she won't. ``They wanted to give me 18 months in jail. I said, `That's ridiculous, I didn't do anything.''' She faces up to 30 years in prison plus $1.5 million in fines, if convicted on all charges.

DOC.HEAD: Saudi Aramco Announces Oil and Gas Find, Third Since July
DOC.TEXT: Saudi Arabian Oil Co. announced Sunday the discovery of a gas and oil field, the third find in six months by the world's largest oil exporter. The announcement from Saudi Aramco headquarters in Dhahran said the strike, in the Raghib area about 77 miles southeast of the Saudi capital of Riyadh, was commercially viable. Testing on Jan. 1 showed Raghib-1 well could produce 3,650 barrels per day, while gas could be produced at the rate of 10 million cubic feet per day, it said. The announcement, distributed by the official Saudi Press Agency, said the oil was of the high-quality, sulphur-free crude found earlier in the year in the Dilam and al-Hawtah discoveries. Saudi Oil Minister Hisham Nazer said Friday that the new oil discoveries south of Riyadh produced oil of the highest quality that could raise Saudi Arabia's per-barrel oil income by $1 to $2. The kingdom already boasts the world's largest single oil reserves, which it estimates at 252 billion barrels. Saudi Aramco has recently intensified its search for new oil deposits in the center of the kingdom, away from the massive producing fields along the Gulf coast. Nazer said in a television interview aired late Friday that the kingdom will seek a higher oil production quota this year and the following years from the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. Nazer said the kingdom was confident that world demand for oil will rise in the 1990's, resulting in satisfactory prices for both producers and consumers. ``Saudi Arabia has been able, through co-operation with its fellow members of OPEC and through contacts with oil producers, to restore stability to the world oil markets,'' Nazer said. ``We are beginning to feel that the situation is improving for the better.'' Nazer's comments echoed those of King Fahd, who said Dec. 31 that the kingdom will work to increase its current OPEC quota of 5.38 million barrels per day. No new target figure was disclosed.
